I'm not too happy about that but that's showbiz folks.  The film was an exciting, thrilling, edge of your seat, in your face roller coaster ride cinematic feast. The CGI was exceptional except for Thanos. He still looked like something out of CGI's earlier days before it was perfected. How they could get that so wrong and unrealistic I have no idea. I've seen games on my grandsons' PS4 that look more realistic than Thanos did.  This particular Avengers' story was fought on three battle fronts so all the characters were never in one place where they could meet one another and hang out. No down time in this movie. Obviously, I expected too much. Mr. Purple (Thanos) seemed to get more screen time than did our real life heroes. The ending though was unbelievably shocking that I never saw coming because I don't read comics and never did growing up. So, yeah, I'm a little out of the loop but I can still love and appreciate the films. I'm sure someone has already spilled the beans but I won't. I'll just say hold back the tears and grit your teeth because you won't see it coming. I walked out of the theater repeating to myself, "are you kidding me, I can't believe this" over and over to myself. Now I've got to wait till 2019 to find out what happens. Well, I hope I'm still here being an older fan. But Marvel Studios wants some more of our hard-earned money fans so we have to wait for part two, which is why I only gave a rating of 8. This is a great Avengers film, the best yet, but it has a very disappointing heart-wrenching cliffhanger. Instead of closure and the defeat of Thanos Marvel gives its fans shock and awe with a bittersweet twist to be continued.  Oh, and yes there were a lot of funny moments, though not nearly enough as Thor Ragnarok.

* THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS * Wow! This movie is amazing. I'm in no way a die hard Marvel fan but I have watched most of the MCU movies and I can safely say that the hype is both warranted and lived up to. Thanos is by far the greatest villain we have seen and of course he should be. The most incredible thing about Thanos was how quickly and strongly I felt emotionally attached to him. The moment when you sacrificed Gamora, I could tell he was genuinely crying and upset. The way he interacts with her as a child shows how much he actually cares for her. Thanos is one of the few villains who I've found myself connecting with. Whilst his goal to wipe out half the universe is in no way a good thing, his motivation for doing it (a cull in order to preserve the finite resources of the universe) is completely believable and makes sense considering the experience he had on his home planet.
When Thanos won at the end of the movie, I couldn't help but feel a bit of happiness for him. As he stood in the sunset and spoke to Young Gamora, I was pleased that he had completed his goal after all of his personal losses. The ending of this movie shocked me. I was expecting the usual "they all lived happily ever after" storyline but the fact that it wasn't like that made this film infinitely better. The fight scenes are choreographed to perfection and the special effects are stunning.
I would go as far to say this is one of the best films I have ever seen and I think it deserves to break all of the box office records.

This is the first review I've ever written, and I think this is the perfect movie to take that spot. This is one of the best movies I've seen in a very long time and my favorite MCU film to date. The humor felt natural to the characters, and not shoehorned in as I felt some of the jokes were in Ragnarok (also an enjoyable film, though). There were some moments of humor that didn't quite land with me, but that's okay. I also very much liked how the handled Thanos and the movie, to me, is more of a Thanos film than an Avengers film. Josh Brolin does an excellent job. There is one particularly emotional scene and I almost began to sympathize with him. Those who have seen the film will know what I'm referring to. There are many surprises and things you won't see coming. I went in only having seen one or two of the trailers, and I'm glad I did. See it as soon as you can and avoid spoilers as much as possible. It is, to me, a truly excellent film. 10/10 would recommend and 10/10 would watch again.

You've probably also read that the movie is so overwhelming that many people are going to have to see it more than once. That also is true. 
What completely blew my mind about this movie is the way it was able to throw the fanbase off in speculation only to show them that they were wrong almost completely 
Every character (aside from 1-2) that dies was predicted to live. While all the characters that people were sure were doomed Were the last ones standing. 
This along with one mindblowingly shocking of a former villain that wasn't advertised at all were the best parts of the movie. 
I liked this movie too much to give it anything less than a 10 but 2 things I didn't like were the cliffhanger and the post credit scene. I feel like some reviewers here aren't comic book fans. Infinity War/Infinity Gauntlet are exactly cheerful, positive stories. Everyone was mad Ragnorak was too silly and now Infinity War was too bleak? It's like there's no win/win with the fans. I liked this movie. It had more of a comic book feel. Is it Marvels best? No. Is it on par with Winter Soldier? No. I don't think we will get one of those again. The Pros:
1) Benedict Cumberbatch is so good at Dr. Strange it's scary. He really has a handle on the role and literally stole every scene he was in. Really enjoy watching him.
2) Chris Hemsworth was also really good. He always gives his all with Thor (despite the stinker Dark World) and it's appreciated.
3) The back story/origin on Gamora was nice. It gave Thanos the "meat" he needed to make him a better villain than most of Marvels bad guys. 
4) I love Tom Holland. I really love, love him as Spider-Man. He was a great choice.
5) The movie had surprises and that was a nice change. Even heroes in comic books die/can't defeat the villain every time. This was SO much better than Ultron and his lackluster defeat.
6) The pacing was good. It moved fast and quickly into action. The Cons:
1) Stop killing Groot. Please?
2) Chris Evans is really phoning it in at this point. He didn't seem like he cared to be there; just living out a contract obligation. That makes me sad. Still think they should have let Falcon rake over as Captain America for awhile (shot Chris in Civil War/put him on ice),
3) A lot of exposition with the CGI. At times the fight scenes were...messy and overly done with CGI and green screen.
4) A few cash cow moments like overdoing the Wakanda stuff, milking the success of Black Panther. 
5) Some characters are "just there" not doing much to advance the story.
6) At times more action than story. I think it's good and worth watching. A very ambitious attempt on the part of Marvel and the writers.  I still think the original Avengers and Winter Soldier were Marvels peak. Not sure if they will ever come close to that again with stories and direction.  8/10

As a Marvel comics and movies fan, I found this film to be quite enjoyable and what I want to see in a MCU film. It has that feel of taking your Marvel action figures out of the toy box and creating your own story. It has the feel of a hash up of multiple characters tossed together fighting against pure evil which works well for this type of film. It has the feel of exactly what I would expect a super hero film to be, and what I would want it to be. With this in mind, I want to examine four aspects I enjoyed and some which I didn't. There are many aspects to like about this film, in my opinion, from the separate stories to the humor to the emotional roller coaster to the development of its main antagonist, this film hits on many marks. To start, I enjoyed the portrayal of different groups pursuing their missions because I really think the multiple stories emboldens what you would find occurring in actual comic story lines. Bringing the MCU a realistic comic book feel. Each group is on a path to prevent/protect something, and given the multitude of characters in the film, this is the best way to handle them - by giving them all individual goals to achieve. These goals is what sets up the plot, while admittedly a simple plot (This is a super hero movie after all), their is still a purpose, a pursuit, and a journey that our heroes travel on which keeps the movie progressing forward. This also works for the movie because it mix and matches different heroes in uniquely pleasant ways, providing the opportunity for humor. This brings me to the second and third aspects I enjoyed about this film. The humor, for me, landed well and increased my enjoyment of the film. Humor is a everyday part of our lives, even when we are faced with challenging situations. This movie does well to keep this aspect of humanity alive in a world where threat of danger isn't only probable, its a reality. Keeping up a lighter air at moments provides a roller coaster ride of sorts,producing a variety of emotions throughout the film. We, the viewer, is taken through this emotional journey just like how the characters themselves experience. This leaves me with strong feelings about events that occur in the film, and any film that can do that gets a high grade from me. Lastly, the development of the main antagonist was one of the greatest aspects of this film. They took a villain and gave him a down to earth persona. They gave him viable and believable motivations. They gave him emotions. All of this results in the need for him to make sacrifices in the pursuit of his purpose. While his intentions may be rooted in good intentions, they still amount to an evil plan that will result in a colossal amount of lost lives. This makes for a completely evil and menacing villain, which is necessarily for a film that has been ten years in the making. Keeping in mind that this is first and foremost a super hero action flick meant solely to entertain, there are still some negative aspects/issues I have concerning this film. What comes to mind first is how some heroes were weaken while others were strengthen. I admit I can get past this, but Marvel should know how to avoid this inconsistency. On the same note, some characters from previous MCU films were no where to be seen. Some characters were left in the same place we returned to in this film. No explanation given, what? Let me remark real quick on the ending since many others have complained about this for one reason or another. All I'm going to say is that we, as viewers and fans, may know what will end up happening in the next movie. I for one will enjoy the ride on how we get there. Just because an assumption may draw us to a particular conclusion, doesn't mean the journey to get there won't be a wealth of entertainment. While I touched on the four main aspects I enjoyed, my enjoyment is not limited to multiple stories, humor, emotional roller coaster, and the antagonist. The directors also did a great job of capturing the tone of each character / film series keeping the spirit of all the MCU franchises continuous. The effects, as usual for an MCU movie, were terrific without overshadowing the performances of its cast. The action scenes were thrilling and inviting, boosting up my adrenaline level and continuing the emotional roller coaster I mentioned. A roller coaster caused from humor, destruction, evil, and the hope for our heroes' success. The film does have lapses in some elements, but that doesn't in any way diminish the enjoyment of this film. Despite the negatives, the film is an overall enjoyable, fun ride through an imaginary world of super heroes.

Avengers: Infinity War is an unrelenting thrill ride of action-packed spectacle. Thanos is easily the best antagonist of the MCU, with genuine moral depth and intimidation (Ebony Maw is also a stand-out). Many characters shine brightly in this film, while others are wasted or used poorly (at least in the theatrical cut). The screenplay has a few problems with exposition, logic and a few tonal shifts. Alan Silvestri's score is incredible, the 2.5 hour running time felt shockingly quick to my pleasant surprise, and the ending is powerfully impactful. Avengers: Infinity War is nevertheless an overwhelming and ambitious blockbuster extravaganza that is the beginning of an even greater culmination for the MCU.

Thanos as a character was the showstopper for me throughout the entire movie. I have never had any interest in such supervillains featured before in movies and cartoons because they seemed to be too powerful and without any flaws. Also, on the represention side, they looked too CGI-ey to the point that they were merely characters from an overly done cutscene in a generic video game. However, Thanos became very appealing to me throughout the progression of the story in Avengers 3 and I became heavily invested in his character arc. He is definitely among the most fleshed out in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, almost to the point where I was rooting for his cause, having a strong emotional connect with him, rather than siding with the good guys. This was a very non classical comic book villain with a lot of moral relativism . The CGI was very good in depicting Thanos' grandeur. It actually felt like a 10 ft tall guy, who was very imposing and charming, having his way onscreen. Not any of the uncanny valley silliness going on. The motion capture of the actor Josh Brolin's facial expressions blended seamlessly with the digital build of Thanos. Also, Josh Brolin did a fantastic job on his own bringing this titan to life. There were some plot points where the character of Thanos did in retrospect sort of act like a fool but Josh's acting easily helped evade that observation while watching the movie. My only big gripe with the movie was when it kept going back to the plight of Scarlet Witch and Vision as a couple. Their chemistry was very bland , boring and cliched and the scenes that featured them were the only instances the film moved very slowly to me. Almost to the point I kept looking at the time on my phone waiting for it to pass.I was least interested in those characters.I just wish they were written such that they both took a cyanide pill and saved the audience the trouble of keeping up with their Twilight romance nonsense. Also, there is a certain cameo in this film by a certain someone and I like how the physical build of the character that the person portrayed was a direct subversion of the actor's actual physical stats.  Overall, a damn good enjoyable popcorn movie having a solid A+ villain.

The movie starts an incredibly fast past, largely because the tension has already been built up in the after credits of the previous films (Thano's 2-3 cameos). The star of this film is definitely Josh Brolin, as he displays unique emotional depth as the nihilistic villian Thanos. I don't think I've seen another movie that packs quite so much into the time frame given I wouldn't have cut or added anything. After the film was over, everyone in the theater said something similar to "I need to go sit down and think about what just happened." This is likely due to the emotional shifts, the constant struggle of the characters, and the sense of unending dread the movie makes you feel. I gave this movie 10 stars, because there really isn't any valid criticism to give. This was an incredibly hard movie to pull off and my hat goes off to the guys at Marvel and the directors for being able to do so. I'm excited for Part 2 and the next Phase of the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

Avengers: Infinity War-the Marvel super-creation carrying the gargantuan expectations of millions of die-hard fans and the buildup of 18 great films before it has finally been delivered to us and all I can say is that it is the best 10th anniversary gift, anyone could ever have wanted. An all-powerful villain, a lineup of all our favorite characters (barring two important ones) and the magic of Marvel make for an invigorating tale of classic good vs. evil where our heroes try to stop a galactic warlord on a murderous agenda to wipe out half the population of the universe by collecting all six infinity stones. The opening is quite grim and the scenes, just from the first five minutes (which directly tie in with Thor:Ragnarok), establish exactly how intimidating, catastrophic and mighty our villain- Thanos is. This also pretty much prognosticates the tone of the rest of the film. Watching Infinity War is like cheering for your beloved team at a highly unpredictable and exciting game of theirs where one moment you're hooting away at the top of your lungs and in the other, you're seeing them going through a low. Yet through all the madness and chaos the film somehow finds stability. It is thrilling to witness the grand entries of the heroes you grew up with and them tossing the bad guys in the air but it is equally so, no matter how heartbreaking as well, to see them fight to the nail, stare hopelessness in the face and still put on a courageous smile and battle on and truly reach their breaking points, for that is what brings out the humanness of them all. Their inability to ignore the guidance of their moral compasses and turn stone-cold like Thanos is one of the big differences that stand out and while it may have seemingly made things tougher for them, is in my belief, that which will hand them victory too.  From edge-of-the-seat anxiety-inducing to hilarious to devastating, this film will take you through a large part of the spectrum of human emotions and yet not once does it tip off balance. The humor is tastefully placed and while admittedly the impact of certain scenes could have been heightened, such small flaws can easily be forgiven just by looking at the artfulness by which the Russo brothers have been able to include so many different characters in such an eventful and complex plot without missing to hold the unwavering attention of the viewers and maintain their heart rates at a constant mark quite surely, slightly above the normal. Apart from this, the different parallel story arcs, too, run meaningfully side-by-side and converge in a finale of epic proportions although the ultimate one is only going to come a whole year later.  Thanos, is given an extra layer of character such that even a being like him, so cruel and madly obsessed with death is shown to have a part of him that knows what love is and that punishes his heart with regret which is something that just enrichens the quality of the slight amount of character development that this film had to do. Also, despite his clearly fearsome personality, the Avengers come infuriatingly close to defeating him at instances and this goes to show that there is still reason to keep hope alive as even Thanos is not invincible. The film's main intention, however, was to tease the overgrown ardor and sentiments attached to every single superhero that appeared and give it all an intensity like never before and it has most definitely done that.  The execution of the action scenes with all their zest and visual flair will leave you awestruck for sure, although in a couple of them the CGI came out a bit tacky. I would recommend watching this movie within the first few days of its release when all the theatres are packed because the environment created by so many people who all love the same thing will take the movie-watching experience to a different state altogether. A glorious feat and achievement and yet another feather in the cap, Infinity war will make you laugh passionately and cry just as much and may even leave you disoriented due to its shocking and brave ending. Do stick around for the post-credits scene though as it sets up what's about to come and will leave you desperately hungry for more.

Avengers: Infinity War surely challenges to be one of the greatest movies of all time. The Russo brothers brilliantly bring together our favourite and most familiar characters from the MCU, from the Avengers, to the Guardians. "Dread it, run from it. Destiny still arrives." I remember walking into the theatre to watch 'The Avengers' in 2012 and completely awed by it. And now I've watched it, the movie that all the previous ones were leading up to.  The expectations were already high and I was doubting how they were going to top Civil War which was my favourite Marvel movie. I was glad the Russo's directed it because they did a MARVELous job.  From the first scene till the last one, I was on the edge of the seat. It did everything it should and even more. It wasn't an Avengers movie, it was Thanos' movie. We already learnt about all the other good guys, so they focused the most on Thanos. And Thanos became my favourite MCU villain. Not only was he scary but also had emotions with some of the characters. He's not just a villain who wants to destroy, he had his reasons. (That's what I loved about Magneto too).  BFI IMAX 3D felt like a rollercoaster ride that I would love to try again and again. The visual effects were spectacular, much better than Black Panther. The action scenes were some of the best I've seen. There were so many scenes during which the entire theatre just cheered and clapped. Even I clapped until my hands hurt. It was that exciting. The score, of course, is amazing.  The ending. I was just shocked. (It's like GoT + Superhero movies). I praise them for having the balls to do it. I doubt even DC would do it. Bravo for that. I was satisfied with it but I do think that's not the real ending. But I'm excited to see how they're gonna pull it off.  Overall, it wasn't just a movie, it was an experience. So far, I couldn't find any major flaws that affected my experience. I had ton of fun. That's what matters. I'm going rewatch it 'infinite' times. Again, I love movies in general, and I'm not a huge Marvel fan. But seeing those characters in a movie like this were so thrilling. I'd rate 10/10 because it was a hugely difficult job to pull off and they did it.

A towering achievement in modern day blockbuster storytelling, Infinity War hits hard right out of the gate, and continues to pummel you with spectacle beyond compare throughout its nearly three hour run time. 
While it's thrilling to see so many amazing characters meeting, and sharing the screen, make no mistake, this is very much a film about Thanos. Brolin's performance as the Mad Titan shines throughout the film. He is both bombastic and nuanced. Terrifying, and fallible. Thanos is now by far the MCU's most fantastic and interesting villain. 
Weaving together so many characters and storylines could easily have gone horribly wrong, but the Russo brothers navigate it seamlessly as they take us through the story, and from planet to planet at an almost break neck speed. It's no surprise that it's thrilling and hilarious to see Tony Stark interact with Doctor Strange, or Thor banter with Star Lord. Every character gets their moment and their chance to shine a bit(Spiderman and Doctor Strange were both standouts for me personally)even if that's all they get. Because the film never really slows down, you shouldn't expect a lot of character growth, or deep narrative arcs for any of our heroes. We've had eighteen films for that, and this is about seeing them all play and interact in this world together. This is an event film after all, and can really only be judged in the context of the MCU's entirety. There's no denying that Infinity War's greatest weakness is its assumption that you are very invested in these characters and storylines. So when I sit back to judge its quality as a film, I do so as a fan of the franchise and as someone who has seen all the films many times. Basically what I'm saying is there is no way for this film to really stand alone. If you haven't seen or didn't like most of the other MCU films, you will be very confused right from the start. 
In the end, this film absolutely belongs to Thanos, and we are all the better for it. Grade: A-

Avengers: Infinity Wars, is an epic saga from the Marvel Cinematic Universe, as the Avengers rebel against the existential threat that is the overwhelming might of the supreme Thanos
The heroes of the narrative (Downey, Pratt, Johansson and the rest of the gang) are in excellent fighting form (as per usual) and bring undertones of organic humour (particularly Ruffalo and Holland) to balance the impending doom. 
Brolin's, Thanos is an infallible, and unmatched talent among previous Marvel Cinematic Universe villains. The leading antagonist (Brolin) could potentially challenge Heath Ledger's maniacal depiction of the Joker. This is not because Thanos is a megalomaniac and indomitable being, but his excellency lies rational. He is deft and absolute in both words and actions. He displays something inexplicably and hauntingly human about him. Thus, making him a fully realized anti-hero.
Alan Silvestri's beautiful layered soundtrack heightens the emotional intensity of the Avengers greatest threat to date. His ability to capture the constantly changing tone and as the inextricably linked narrative jumps from place to place is deserving of praise. 
The Russo's Infinity Wars (Part 1) is sure to become a pop culture reference of the future, as they have managed to achieve with the Thanos and the Avengers what Bryan Singer failed to do with Apocalypse (a character of banal platitude) and the X-Men. But we are left with our appetites unsated, and waiting with both repressed clamour and bated breath for the conclusion of the enthralling and dynamic journey in 2019.
-RJ

This is what the Marvel Cinematic Universe to date was working towards. It's the culmination of 10 years of interwoven plots and character arcs. And boy, does Avengers: Infinity War deliver. The movie manages to find an almost perfect balance of action, drama, and humour (there a couple of truly hilarious scenes). While the movie is long with 2 hours, 40 minutes of running time, it never feels so. If you are a fan of the past MCU installments, you will find this to be one of the best movies of the series, that will shake to you to the core. But this leads me to essentially the biggest problem of the movie: it's pretty much exclusively targeted at hardcore fans of the MCU. While you (most likely) will be able to follow the plot, you will have a hard time to untangle the web of relationships between the heroes, to unstand how they got in their current situation, and in some cases even to identify them: a couple of major characters never even gets addressed by name once in the whole movie.  In addition, it will be difficult to feel emotional attached to the heroes. While every of the protagonists gets their moment to shine, there's very little characterisation or even development. A small number of crucial characters get a single emotional scene, or maybe two, but this is barely enough to make you sympathetic to their plight. Pretty much all of your investment in the heroes will have to come from the previous movies of the MCU. On the other hand, the movies antagonist Thanos gets thoroughly characterised and fleshed out. This is what makes Avengers: Infinity War really special and standing out in the mass of MCU movies. A villain with true depth. While his actions are cruel and atrocious, he doesn't act out of a wanton lust for destruction but rather out of a twisted sense of duty and even a perverse way of... kindness. Josh Brolin's subtle motion-captured performance further helps to make Thanos despite his bloodthirsty savagery appear human and almost relatable.

For the last 10 years Marvel has led up to this. All your favorite characters in one movie for an ultimate showdown. But if you aren't familiar with any MCU film before, you'll be completely lost. This is the cliffhanger-season finale of your favorite show. So brush up on your Marvel knowledge if it's been a while and sit back because this may be the best MCU flick to date.

Avengers Infinity War was based of the 1991 publication Infinity Gauntlet. In terms of scale, the movie was done well to translate to the big screen. There's no way it could have been done as it played out in the comics as the latter series of Infinity Gauntlet involved Marvel's comics entities(Eternity, Galacticus, The Watchers, The Celestials, etc...) and that would have been way too much. Although it would be very cool to have one or two show up in the final installment to say lend a helping hand and receive and introduction into the MCU. I've read other reviews where it stated that certain deaths lacked emotional punch as they were killed or eliminated only to have their deaths reversed in the final installment. Well, that's how it works in the comics. Death has way since been handled as temporary in both Marvel and DC comics. The other deaths that appeared to be more permanent were done well and I doubt those characters will resurface. There were some characters whose power sets seemed to get amped up quite a bit, i.e. Captain America while others seemed dialed down. Therefore, the way they were handled in battle made them seem a bit like some baby Hulks. And given how formidable Thanos would be with just one stone, the battle sequences were done well to provide the viewer with a sense of legitimacy. Because as shown in the comics, he could have easily defeated many of the characters in the movie with one or two stones, let alone five as he had when he arrived on Earth. I thought Thor's arc was handled well and he was finally given some scenes that actually provide some insight on his true power set and what he is capable of. So outside of the ignant mofos that sat behind and talked most of the movie, it was quite an enjoyable bit of escapism. Thanos was believable and given how much had to be played out in the movie, his character was well done with just enough character development to understand his motivation. The 2 hour 40 minute running time seems to fly by. It's pretty much 0-60 within the first 10 minutes of the movie. So give it a go. If you're a fan boy, you'll understand why much of the movie was shot and made the way it was. Those who don't read comics may have a harder time suspended their sense of belief. Titan was shown as more of a planet as opposed to a moon which it is. That Earthlings could survive on a moon of Saturn without some type of armor or space gear is beyond me. But maybe I'm nitpicking. Go check it out, you'll enjoy yourself.

No Spoilers, just reference to trailers. Going into this movie I had seen countless reviews from both critics and fans alike. Some people suggesting that this isn't even one of the best movies in the entire MCU. So I went in with mixed expectations.  Firstly, I'm not a huge Marvel fanboy, I wasn't even a huge fan of some of the recently popular films like Black Panther and Homecoming which I thought could've been far better. I loved Infinity War and I honestly don't know how I didn't go in expecting to, because halfway through the movie I was literally looking at a friend in amazement because of how awesome the movie was.  A lot of the criticism of this movie are towards the following; The ending, uncharacteristic behaviour, black order cgi, strength relativity based on other movies/comics, screen time (which I find hilarious), tone, and anticipation of this movie.  I will try and keep this brief The Ending - People either love it or hate it. But I definitely think people hate it for the wrong reasons. All I can say is that, for the most anticipated movie of all time, it is amazing that despite all the theories I read, I was pleased that I was still surprised by how things turned out by the end. The execution was great as well and mostly made sense. Uncharacteristic behaviour - I literally think ONE character was unusual throughout the movie. With so many other characters bringing their game, I literally could not have cared less. There was also one blatantly stupid move which ruined everything in a moment that I felt was unbelievable. Thats it though...plenty going on otherwise. CGI for Black Order - I say specifically the Black Order because no one can argue that this isn't one of the most gorgeous movies out now, and I don't just mean in the action sequences. The Black Order I thought were fine, its just its in comparison to how amazing Thanos looked. It never took me out of the moment. I for one just appreciated their design. Strength Relativity - This I think is the most complicated thing for people to understand about Marvel movies especially. Sometimes I understand the criticism, in the sense that, some people just shouldn't be as powerful as others (e.g. Black Widow is not as powerful Scarlet Witch) and yet they clearly are in the movie. Again these instances are minor. However, what annoys me is the - "why didn't he just do that earlier" argument, or "why can't he just do that thing he did before". In general, I think that those are people going into this movie asking to hate, in the sense that they go into this movie with the mindset that it will be a popcorn movie. You cannot enter the movie with that mindset. I would love to go into detail about this but it would take forever. Essentially its almost like asking why we walk or jog if we can sprint. People, regardless of their nature have limits, especially in intense situations. It happens in action and people need to get over it. Essentially, most of the fight scenes are incredible, some outstanding, but you have to be smart about them without being too smart to fully enjoy them. Screen Time - For all I care, they could've cut out a few more characters and I would've still been ecstatic to see most people joining together cause when they did, it was awesome. Yes - some pairings work far better than others, this is true. But again, only because those pairings are literally amazing. The pairings that weren't as good were simply the ones that met my expectation. E.g. Captain America and Black Panther are obviously not going to be as fun as Strange and Tony. And yes not all the characters were in the movie. Its has a limited runtime, and there is another one coming next year. It shouldn't be a criticism for the movie because it asking for more where there is already so much. It's like complaining about owning an island because you wanted a country, it's a ridiculous criticism. Tone - I can't understand how someone can't appreciate the rollercoaster of emotions this movie provided. A cinematic experience should be one that makes you feel strongly and the highest praise I can give this movie is, these days, you go into great movies that excel in two genres at most. This movie almost excelled on its comedy, action, thrill and drama altogether. The most pleasantly balanced movie I've ever seen. Anticipation - As I said earlier I have seen some ridiculous criticism for this movie. I didn't go into this movie with the anticipation in my mind. I didn't go in wanting it to be the best movie in the world. Nor did I go in with lowered expectations, I went in as Thanos would've said "Perfectly balanced". I think that a lot of people went in with some unrealistic expectations, something thats easy to do with this movie. If you haven't seen this movie yet go and see it, preferably in a packed cinema because as I said before, it is one for an audience. The is the highest 9/10 I could ever give. It misses out on a 10 because it is not perfect, only because it could've been even better than it was. It frustrates me because if it was, this would easily be one of the best movies I have ever seen and will ever see. Nevertheless I believe its fair to say it lived up to the hype and the hype was huge.

Avengers: Infinity war is a solid base foundation that wastes not an ounce of time in setup territory. Instead, the more relevant plan is just to do the things that the first eighteen MCU movies have long been leading up to, being a decade for that matter.  First up, the action is an absolute win factor that frequently elevates the movie in the direction it should be going right where it initiates. The script-writing with essential MCU humor remains intact as to be usually expected. Both the heroes and villains have their equal bargain of screentime. And to put the lackluster theory to rest, Thanos alongside the rest of his forces attributes to one of the more significant beings of villainy thus far. The cameos and particularly some eye-popping returns are perhaps the ultimate power up mid way through. It really does however feel as though the element that gets this ambitious threequel stirring along is the dynamics between characters typically as they encounter one another for the first ever time. Just when it seemed like the pace might be draggy and formulaic, it really wasn't. Only the shuffle might not necessarily have been executed at peak level. Now just to make things fairly simple, the teamwork in every action scene is enough to keep you intrigued. The duration per action scene isn't quite as long enough, thereby making it seem that Civil War's airport battle remains the top tier contender for a well earned time being.  Spider-Man is great but it feels like his whole depiction works in the MCU more by weakness than strength. Comically, it works. But maybe his stakes could broaden up in the future. I get that there were plenty of others too. The X-Men/ FF deal isn't here too soon for a live action crossover. Maybe now we'll relish the blast of the Avengers and Guardians together. Fair enough, I'd reckon. The visuals felt breathtaking and genuinely on point. What's with these trailer shots that don't make the cut anyway?  The adventure this movie sets foot upon doesn't weigh down the plotlines. Yet it would seem that characters exist, do their stuff. Maybe not as hugely as a collection as any wild expectation ought to get. Maybe Civil War was where the Russos timed the juggle right, and this time the priorities seemed like a shift from previous executions. It's thankful enough to say this movie didn't have any setback that made it suck. The sound editing is suitably good. The final act felt reasonable and delivered a fistful of Thanos mayhem. But I'd rather refer to this movie as a combination of heroes than a culmination of efforts. I'm already betting on the next Avengers movie to embark the grander way to prominence.  Oh yes, got to love the post credit scene.  In the end, Infinity War works as much as a teamwork crossover event as it does as a villain biopic depiction. It has enough contention of its own to rank its way to the top MCU movie depending on how you look at it. I haven't listed any spoilers, even though I pretty much read all I could before even watching it. Well, it's my thing as my criteria goes about knowing stuff beforehand and seeing how it plays out in the result. But others probably do not feel the same way so this is entirely spoiler free. I'd hoped for a complete 10 star rating. I really did. The stakes couldn't be better. But I'm starting to think I miss Whedon's work.

Banner is truly terrified by Thanos, as you can see in many parts of the movie, due to their encounter in the very first phase in the movie, where Thanos totally dominates the Hulk which laters clearly shows itself as the Hulk's fear of Thanos and the Hulk not taking over. Loki deserved the completion of his character arc, by meeting his death at the hands of Thanos, paying for his betrayal and failure, though Loki's last moments were akin to a hero, i.e, trying to protect Thor. Also loved the throwback to The Avengers, when Loki tells Thanos, that "we have a hulk". Tony Stark's destiny arrived in a true sense : His fear wasn't himself dying, but seeing his fellow teammates and friends dead (Just like it was shown in Age of Ultron) which happens at the end of the movie. Cap is no longer Cap, only Steve Rogers living his life sort of like a nomad in the past 2 years since the Civil War. Gamora's death was unexpected, but you can clearly see a different side to Thanos when he truly loves his daughter, but has to sacrifice her anyway, for bringing balance to the universe, and fulfilling his destiny by obtaining the Soul Stone. Bummer that Hawkeye and Ant-Man aren't in the movie, but I'm sure they'll prove important in Avengers 4. There's also a clever reveal, that of Red Skull being the guardian of the Soul Stone, after his sudden absence due to the tesseract in the First Avenger. The Wakanda and Titan acts are wonderfully portrayed, with each serving a proper impact to the future of the Avengers. Peter Quill's moment was the deciding one, as if they had gotten the Gauntlet, Thanos wouldn't have defeated all of them. The Wakanda fight scenes are so GOOD, they're Civil War's Airport scene x 10. Now, I'll cut to the points I want to make : comic fans will be slightly disappointed to know there's no Lady Death, or Thanos's mad infatuation with her. Instead this version of Thanos is driven by the need for balance in the universe, given the universe's limited resources. In a way, it does seem okay. There's also the dreaded snap, as in the comics, with Thanos wiping away half the universe. The Guardians fade away, and so do many others, Bucky, Falcon, Doctor Strange, Spider-Man, Nick Fury, Maria Hill, etc etc. Spider-Man's death was very emotional, as you can see Stark's worst fears coming true, with Peter saying "Mr.Stark, I don't want to die", and fading away. Well, this seems as if it was the first Avengers movie where Tony Stark didn't hog the centre of attention. In fact it seems to be pretty evenly spaced between all of the Marvel characters, and with the number that have now come into the franchise, I was wondering how they were going to handle the huge ensemble. Well, it turned out pretty well, though of course when you have so many super heroes all gathered together the bad guy is going to have to be pretty tough, and they outline they quite quickly where he takes down the Hulk.
 This is probably one of those movies that we don't need to say anything about the plot because it has been building up to it for the last ten years, and anyway it is actually based on a comic book series as it is. So, we have this Titan, Thanos (Titan as in an inhabitant of Titan as opposed to one of the old gods from Greek mythology, though Marvel hasn't shied away from borrowing from mythology as it is). He has this plan to depopulate the universe and to do that he needs these stones called Infinity Stones, and when he has all of them he will become invincible. Once again, the movies over the last ten years have been dropping hints as to these stones, and now we have basically come to the climax of that story arc.
 So, the question that is raised, is where to from here. Well, I'm sure the avid comic book readers do have a pretty good idea since there is quite a lot of material that can be borrowed from. However, we also need to remember that this is actually part one of a two part series, so the story isn't over yet. The problem is that with the ending as it is, there isn't all that much room to be able place any movies between the two Avengers movie. However, it seems that we will be seeing Captain Marvel and Ant Man and the Wasp before the grand finale to this Avengers movie.
 Okay, this may be a bit of a spoiler, but then again I have warned you, but characters do die, which is a bit of an oddity because if there is one thing with comic books and that is characters always seem to be able to come back. Well, that seems to be the case with the movies as well because Loki seems have have had some miraculous resurrections. However, I will leave it at that.
 Now Thanos, they certainly have put a lot of effort into creating a villain that works. There are a lot of shallow villains out there, and Thanos certainly isn't one of them. Sure, he has a motive, but it isn't one of those 'I want to conquer the universe' type of motives. In a way he seems to just want a bit of peace and quiet, and the problem is that overpopulation certainly doesn't allow room for that. Sure, he is pretty powerful, and when you are going up against pretty much every single Marvel hero that has appeared to date (with the exception of Ant-Man - he is mysteriously absent in the film), you certainly are going to have to be of a special calibre.
 As for the comedy, well, they certainly have toned it down a lot. It was starting to get to the point where the movies were simply turning into a collection of one liners, particularly with Thor: Ragnarok. However, this wasn't the case here, which did help quite a lot. I do hope they continue along that trend and continue to tone down with it. However, it was a shame that some of the really cool characters from Ragnarok went missing in action as well, but I think the opening scene pretty much explains that.

I've heard and read comments that the humor in the movie wasn't entirely appropriate given the dark nature of the premise. This is Marvel. Marmite - you love the humor or you don't. I do. I'd rate this a solid 9 out of 10. It was definitely the "Empire Strikes Back" of the MCU - or at least that's how it felt. The Russos did a great job of bringing the tone and style of each of the franchises together. Standouts were Thanos and Gamora. We know Spidey, Black Panther will be back as their solo sequels have been announced. Gamora's fate only realy pays off is if she stays 'dead'. I worry that she won't. I love Zoe Saldana and Gamora, but narratively her loss would feel empty if she was resurrected or brought back via time-travel or something like that. Losing Hemidall was emotional as well - but Idris Elba is too big for a cameo part in the MCU. Loki needs to stay dead as well. Tom Hiddleston, for me, is still the standout villain in the MCU, but his death is a catalyst for Thor's story in the movie. With so many characters 'dissolving', it did feel like it devalued some of the other deaths - Gamora, Loki, Heimdall. This is the reason i can't give it a 10 out of 10. With so many characters to give dialogue and screen time to, fans of specific characters will feel disappointed their favorite didn't get more - especially Black Widow. But great fight between her, Okoye and Proxima Midnight. Thor was an unexpected highlight - the emotional narrative - and great to see the introduction of Stormbreaker. Overall, a fitting way to bring together 10 years of the universe. Was even good to see General Ross and Red Skull. One final thought - great post-credits scene and would love to see the post-credits scene in Captain Marvel, where Brie Larson's Cap receives the encoded distress message from Fury, and she unloads a whole bunch of whoop-ass on Thanos.

SPOILER FREE!!!! DO NOT LET ANYONE SPOIL THIS MOVIE FOR YOU!!!!! So it's officially been 10 years since the MCU has begun (he takes a short break to let out a little cry as he realizes how effing old he is) and more or less I've really enjoyed the films. There have been a couple I wasn't a fan of, and honestly there were only a few I absolutely loved, but this one. THIS ONE! This is Marvels answer to Nolan.  First off, I was amazed at how well the directors and writers balanced the tone and characters. No characters are shoved to the side, they all have ample screen time and serve their purpose. And every time a new character shows up it legitimately feels like their movies tone. When youre with Dr. Strange it feels like his movie, when you're with the Guardians it feels like their movie and so on and so forth. It astounds and impresses the hell out of me that the Russo Brothers were able to pull this off so seamlessly and have it not feel jumbled or clunky, especially seeing as there are so many characters to juggle.  But yeah, let's talk about the big guy. Thanos. 
Now I think it's safe to say the weakest part of the MCU has been their villains, again with a couple exceptions i.e. Loki and Killmonger, but Thanos is easily the best of the entire series and one of the best villains I've ever seen in a movie. Why??? Because he's actually a character!!!!! He's not just some mindless thug looking to destroy the universe because bad guy plot, he's a real, fleshed out character with a tragic background and emotions. There are times when he doesn't want to do the things he's doing but feels he needs to because what he's doing is the best thing for the universe, and while he's clearly insane and evil, you see through his eyes so much it's hard not to empathize with the guy.  This movie is big. It's grand. It's epic on a Lord of the Rings scale. It's funny when it needs to be and it's serious when it needs to be. It perfectly balances all these likable and well developed characters perfectly and has one of the greatest villains in cinema history. There's no other word for it: Avengers - Infinity War is a damn masterpiece that might just dismantle The Dark Knight as my favorite comic book movie. Without a doubt this movie gets a perfect 10/10.

Wow.... Just wow.  Avengers Infinity War: 10 years in the making, this is what the whole of the Marvel Cinematic Universe has been building to and boy is it a shocking, enjoyable surprise.  Directed by the Russo Brothers and starring... everyone, Infinity War finally has Thanos collecting the infinity stones, the most powerful items in the universe, together and all our heroes are in a desperate race to stop him.  There's so much that goes on in this movie it's almost impossible to go into detail without spoilers, right from the get go you know that Infinity War has stakes and hopeless stakes at that. They are pulling no punches and surprised me on multiple occasions with their choices. This is the darkest and edgy-est movie Marvel have made but they still kept their light heartedness for the most part, they turned that happy-go-lucky attitude off when it needed and man did it shock you.  Now, this is a big movie huge in fact. But they somehow managed to keep it very contained. Yes there's the big massive group fight, but for majority of the action and story telling its smaller groups interacting with each other. And that's one of the films highlights, there is not a huge team up of every single hero. Instead there's around 3 groups of smaller teams (with 3 different plot lines) and this allows us to see heros we wouldn't otherwise see work and fight together to great effect. And Infinity War does a great job balancing our hero stories with Thanos', yes Thanos has a story and an arc. Speaking of which.  Thanos. Big purple headed CGI Ron Perlman Thanos.... 
He works. 
Everything that has been said about Thanos is completely thrown of the table in the first 5 minutes of Infinity War. He is incredibly intimidating and utterly compelling, whether speaking or letting his actions for him. But not only that you almost find yourself sympathising with him and understanding his motives and choices in the movie. You kinda get his thought process. This makes him a fantastic villain. I thought I'd never see a good CGI villian but Thanos definitely proves me wrong.  And I've unlike other marvel movies, I have no idea where they are going to take this. And that is Infinity Wars greatest triumph. Unpredictably. At no point did you know for definite what was going to happen. And you felt that in the cinema. There's of course an after credit scene. Normally around half the audience leave before this comes around, here no one moved an inch.  The only things going against Infinity War is the start can be a tad clunky. Because over the 10 years of Marvel so many different film makers and writers have worked on these characters pulling all that together at times didn't fit correctly. 
Also the very fact that there's 10 years of pervious movies (18 not including Infinity War), am not sure if casual viewers will get the same impact as those who've seen every single one. Am sure they'll be able to understand the gist of Infinity War but they may have a few questions.  This movie is a blast and came as a complete surprise, which I have no idea where they're going to next. I give Avengers Infinity War an A.  And it was pretty damn cool seeing Edinburgh get punched like that.

The Avengers unite to battle their most powerful enemy, Thanos.  On a mission to collect all six Infinity Stones, Thanos plans to use the artifacts to inflict his twisted will on reality.  The fate of the planet and existence itself has never been more uncertain as everything the Avengers have fought for has led up to this moment.... After ten years of big budget, even bigger box office movies, here's lies the first key to the conclusion of all three phases, and was it worth the wait?
Yes, and then some. This is the movie that holds the key to ten years of dedication and respect to some of the most beloved comic book characters ever created, and even though it boasts an absolute plethora of characters, they are all included, even though Stark, Rogers, and Thor predictably get the lions share of the screentime. The film is almost split into three, we have different arcs. One featuring Stark, Parker, and Strange. One featuring Thor and The Gaurdians. And the other featuring the rest of the Avengers preparing for Thanos. As for the audience, we could have never been prepared for Thanos, easily the most humanistic MCU villain since Killmonger, and his goal is simple, collect all six stones in order to create a more tranquil and peaceful universe. Is he really the epitome of all evil, after all, his purpose is sound to him, even if it is genocidal, and this makes him such a difficult and complex villain. There are times when he has to make difficult decisions, there are times when it seems that he may be able to be reasoned with. But this is their infinite adversary, and it really has been worth the wait, it really has been worth sitting through a few clunkers, because this semi conclusion goes way beyond what you have been building up for, and to say that the Russo Brothers have gone dark for this, is an understatement. It still has that wonderful sense of humour that has been rife throughout the films, and the chemistry between all characters is seamless, but the final third will have your mouth left gaping, especially if you have invested so much time with this universe. As expected, the effects are amazing, and even if Thanos looks like Bruce Willis, you soon forget he is a walking creation of the computer. But with the ending, it's either one of the biggest red herrings committed to celluloid, or the Disney/Marvel monster are aware of superhero fatigue, and are not scared of sacrificing a few franchises. Believe the hype, and then some, this is the movie event of the decade, and it has the best ensemble cast since The Longest Day. Next year cannot come quick enough.....

The Avengers super-mash-up has out-done itself once again: more heroes, fiercer baddies, grander scope, and greater peril. It's almost too much and yet not enough in other ways, because the screen time for many characters get spread so thin. Assuming you have seen most of the MCU movies up to this point, you'll appreciate that a handful of the characters previously under-developed have gotten more attention, but many of the favorites who were previously better-developed got barely enough time to be a cue for a crowd cheer. For some of them, it felt like the actors/actresses couldn't even get into character or understand the context of the scene -- one may posit that the secrecy over the whole plot had a negative impact on their performances. While the heroes may have come from the pages of comic books, their foes seemed to have come from grotesque video games. The setup is familiar: the big-bad has a handful of one-dimensional lieutenants and a horde of violent minions/beasts/robots/whatnot. However, I would say that Thanos was the star of the show, in a way we haven't seen nor talked about since the first Avengers (the enigmatic Loki). Not only is Thanos powerful, but this Mad Titan has some depth, development, and determination that's typically reserved the good guys. This is an epic that I will surely like to watch again soon, because so much just whizzed by in a blur the first time, and there was more than one reason for that! This was my first visit to a new-ish 3D venue that might need to have some kinks worked out, because I felt the visuals were really muddy and dizzying during many fast action sequences -- more than the usual 3D blur. Maybe it was a technical issue with this particular showing, but personally I would recommend going to a non-3D showing.

There's almost no way of reviewing this movie without containing spoilers. Infinity War was everything the fans asked for, and sometimes even more. So many surprising elements and REALLY emotional scenes. The movie begins brutally by killing off Loki in just seconds. It tells you right away what kind of film this will be, and boy does it get darker throughout the way. Yes, there were MANY jokes and while some didn't land, at least Marvel finally managed to even out the jokes with the serious and emotional scenes (unlike Thor ragnarok and GOTG vol. 2). This time there wasn't some silly cringe reference or dance off when stuff was going down. Although the movie did feel a little choppy towards the first quarter, it immediately crafted itself together beautifully halfway throughout the final act. It just kept getting better and better, while getting more intense too. Whenever Thanos popped up all your attention was drawn to him. It was like Darth Vader, everyone in the room (not just in the film) acknowledged his presence and feared him. Josh Brolin by far stole the show as Thanos. His facial expressions and menace actually for once made up for a real threatening villain. Just when you thought stuff couldn't get any worse, it did. And it just kept going on and on until the whole audience got teary. Watching Thanos fight Tony gave me goosebumps, as I expected this to be the end of Tony. Everyone slowly fading away did make you lose hope. By far the most emotional scene for me was when Peter was crying on Tony while he knew what was about to happen. This movie didn't hold back at all. It was just menacing and everything hit you in the face so quickly. All the avengers showed got their moments of epicness, ESPECIALLY Thor. The end does leave many questions on everyone's minds as well as theories. But that's what makes it so good. My biggest fear with this film (apart from the potential cringe comedy) would be feeling done after IW. But nope, this just makes me want see Avengers 4 like right now. I want to see what happens next.  This film truly felt like an epic, and its grand scale of setting and characters really supported that fact. All the avengers were turned up more than ever as they realized this was quite possible the end of all things. Directing such a massive film with so many things going on at once is not an easy task. That's why I bumped this movie from an 8 to a 9, because I respect all the effort put into it plus the fact that it felt coherent most of the time. Not to mention the emotional scenes were powerful as well. This movie was jaw dropping and Marvel just reminded everyone why the Avengers are the BEST superhero group in any set of superhero films. We know these characters, we know their desires, and we've known them for 10 years. Now we are witnessing the end product. Avengers 4, come quick!

Marvel's Infinity War soars as it gives us what the franchise has promised ever since 2012's The Avengers. Out of all of this film's ambitions, the most impressive feat remains to be on delivering a Thanos that is menacing, intriguing, and astoundingly tragic. This leads to a film that is epic at its core, yet emotional and patient in its execution.  The standout of this film is arguably its main character, Thanos. It is through him that we see a villain that does not boast about how evil he is for the sake of being evil. He does not twirl his moustache and no longer sits idly on his chair basking at how destiny is at the palm of his hands. His pursuit and end goal in the film is portrayed as something noble. It is one that requires consequential sacrifices to be made and he believes that what he is doing is faultless and the right thing. He understands pain and loss and we see that throughout the film. He laments the countless lives he has lost and especially the things that he genuinely cares about. He believes that it is his burden to carry out his task of collecting the Infinity Stones and that he is the only one willing enough to save the Universe through his own means. He is the ultimate antithesis to the Avengers. It also surely helps that Josh Brolin's portrayal of him, even though mostly CGI, is one that shows an abundance of depth and a commanding presence to the character. Meanwhile, it is made clear here that the Avengers exhibit themselves as those who happen to believe that even one life sacrificed is not a cost that they are willing to take. It is through them that Thanos reveals their goals as futile and short-sighted. This theme is hammered home even more by showing how "Earth's Mightiest Heroes" are still hopelessly divided through numerous planets and locations. Fresh from the events of Civil War, Tony and Steve are still not on speaking terms and the threat of galactic destruction could not have come in a more terrible time.  That doesn't mean that there aren't plenty of character dynamics that are absolutely brilliant. To name a few, Cumberbatch and Downey give phenomenal and unwavering performances that mostly pay-off the peril and torture that they've been expecting to arrive for years now through the destruction of life itself. Holland also gives a vulnerable and obviously young side to him even at the midst of the end of the world. Hemsworth shows off his acquired personality from Ragnarok, yet still shaken and jagged because of what's at stake. He shines as his role as the God of Thunder has never seen this much significance compared to prior outings. His interaction with the Guardians is the perfect bridging of both worlds that we knew was already coming sooner or later. Rocket and Groot are also given an unexpected role along with Thor that was fun and unique to watch. Speaking of the Guardians of the Galaxy, Gamora and Quill standout as their worried and broken past comes back to haunt them. Gamora particularly shines as the daughter of Thanos, which gives a sense of history and affliction for both characters. Each character drives home the grim and merciless danger that they are in. The stakes are still high and it is made clear for each sequence. Nonetheless, this is all not to say that this movie lost the usual Marvel trademarks of quips and lighthearted fun. It's still definitely an Avengers movie and how the characters organically and hilariously complement each other just makes their eventual collapse and downfall even more tragic and heartbreaking. On a technical standpoint, the film is visually breathtaking and ups the scale to planets and worlds previously unimaginable. The blending of both the Guardians, the Avengers and Thanos himself breathes an entire universe into life and it feels lived in and familiar. The action scenes are definitely on point and take center stage in this film. The Russo brothers have learned a lot ever since they took the directing helm in Captain America: The Winter Soldier. The film presents the action as it is and does not opt in for shaky cams or obviously recognizable body doubles. They do not disappoint, aside from set pieces being a little too short lived as the film has to constantly go back to other side stories happening planets away. It's understandable as it has to juggle this huge ensemble of a cast that already had their own character developments and movies prior to this one. However, when a Lord of the Rings-esque battle is ensuing, it doesn't help when the film steps back from it to show a side story which we inevitably all know where it will lead it up to. Aside from that, other minor complaints are how the film's score shy away from using the individual themes to symbolize the heroic moments of their respective heroes. The Guardians of the Galaxy theme or the Spider-Man Homecoming theme are a few examples that are not present in the movie.  In the end, this film will leave you speechless, disturbed, and perturbed. It's something that Marvel has successfully made us feel after 10 years with most of these characters. It's a unique cinematic experience that any other franchise or movie comes close to nowadays. Infinity War essentially created a cultural phenomenon that will be discussed further in years to come. Verdict: 4.5/5

I always enjoy a surprise at the cinema, I just didn't expect to be surprised in the way that I was. I've invested a lot of time in the MCU, and just when I think I'm tiring of superhero films, Marvel step their game up again. They did it with Ragnarok, Winter Soldier, Spiderman Homecoming, Ant Man, Dr Strange... these were all films that I wasn't so much as excited, more nervous that they might finally start underwhelming after 10 years of very serviceable and more often than not extremely good film-making. I, however, expected Infinity War to deliver. And it did. The gravity of this film just felt so much bigger. All the traditional "they'll have a couple of punch ups, but nothing will really happen" worries faded completely in the opening sequence. This was a film that meant business. The action scenes were great - especially the battle in Wakanda. It was LOTRs -esque. Quips aplenty, and some very good acting (Holland especially) made this film extremely watchable, and the CGI was magnificent. Where the storyline strains a tad, the screen still pops and the characters really feed off each other. I, like many others in the build up, was worried about the law of diminishing returns with so many characters on screen. However, the Russo brothers took a step back and approached it logically - don't have them all in the same place. It worked very well, and whilst certain characters really did cry out for more screen time, there were no real complaints. Why? Because this film, whilst an Avengers film, is really all about... Thanos. My god. How wrong I was. I was so against yet another wooden CGI villain, but Brolin and the CGI team have nailed one of the most memorable super-villains in... well, all time. There are problems with the consistency of his powers and how he uses them, but he really dominates both the screen and the movie as a whole. Thanos manages to actually be fearsome, where so many other Marvel villains have failed. He's got a cliched backstory, yet you can still empathise with him. I never expected Thanos to have so much depth. Thanos is the real triumph of this film, which is the biggest surprise by a longshot. For me, he's as ground-breaking as the first time we saw Serkis' Gollum on the big screen. Infinity War certainly sits in the upper echelons of the MCU to date. With the new raised stakes, I find myself refreshed and reinvested in the franchise, and desperately awaiting news on how both Ant-Man and Captain Marvel come into this story. Because, at the moment, you truly believe in Thanos' power, and the futility of the Avengers' plight.

Alright so I'm going to try my best to keep this as a NON-SPOILER REVIEW, as there are many shocking plot twists and surprises and I wouldn't want to ruin that experience for you. Wow! What a ride! This film was everything I wanted it to be! Exciting, thrilling, and beautifully crafted over the course of 10 years and 19 films. Yes, I have waited for this ever since the inception of the MCU back in 2008, but more importantly as someone who read Jim Starlin's Infinity Gauntlet series 17 years ago. It was breathtaking and jaw dropping to see something of this scope come to life on the big screen from the very same comics I read as a child. @therussobrothers did an amazing job balancing the tone of all the characters (comedic and serious tones) and giving every character their spotlight without making it feel too overcrowded or bloated. The action itself in some of the scenes were taken directly from the pages of Hickman's 'Infinity' run couple of years ago which made me really happy to see. Although there were a lot of surprises in the film, the one element that surprised me the most was the amount of emotional weight that the film carried, it really helped develop certain character arcs especially Thanos, and man oh man when Thanos comes on screen, he really steals it! Not only is he frightening and intimidating, but he has a very grounded and philosophical twist to his character that makes you sympathize for him and his surprisingly emotional motivations. Action was great and easy to follow with no shaky cams this time (yaaaaay!), but the overall story and execution was better than Civil War and Winter Soldier (which everyone knows I love to death). In the end this was everything I hoped and wanted to see in an Infinity War film and I really can't wait for Avengers 4 next year! Whatever you do, see this film before someone spoils it for you as there are many idiots going and spoiling it for others who haven't had the time to see it on opening day! Make sure you experience it in IMAX if you have one next to you, the screen is much bigger and visuals look more vibrant and sharp! Oh and there is one post credit scene so stick around after the credits for a treat!

This is one of the most anticipated movies of the year for many people. The hype surrounding this movie after ten years of buildup in the Marvel Cinematic Universe is something many fans have been looking forward to for a long time. I have to admit, I too was greatly looking forward to this movie. After having seen it on a packed Thursday night IMAX showing, I am more than satisfied.  Possibly this movie's greatest accomplishment is how successfully it manages to balance its massive cast. Most everyone in this movie gets a noteworthy role or a shining moment in the film. Most of the characters got what I found to be a reasonable amount of screentime. To me this is an immense feat, one which I remain impressed by. I found the choices of which characters got to interact together through their storylines to be quite smart, making for a very entertaining and funny movie to watch.  This movie successfully manages to retain that wonderful Marvel fun, in what was advertised as quite a dark movie. The comedy in this movie is very present, but almost never when it is unwelcome. It succeeds in being funny an impressive amount of the time, while still mixing well around the dark aspects of the story. That was all balanced very nicely.  I think that this movie did a very good job with tone, I imagine it was a very difficult process to figure out how to juggle these different connecting storylines with tonally different characters originating from different movies. I thought that it was, like most of this movie, very impressively balanced and handled. Maybe once do I recall a tone shift being a little too dramatic, but that was a very minor hiccup that did not impact the overall movie whatsoever. The way they managed to balance the comedy and the menace of Thanos and his mission is quite excellent indeed.  This was what I was initially worried about, Thanos. But man I was completely needlessly worried. Thanos is easily one of Marvel's best villains to date, not just from Josh Brolin's great performance and the impressive cgi, but from the believability and engaging nature of Thanos as a villain. Thanos is such a captivating villain, and the movie does a wonderful job at showing why he believes that everything he is doing is for the greater good. Like many great villains, he believes in what he does, he's not just bad for the sake of bad. I believe the movie really sells that, which is a crucial point to his character being compelling. Equally importantly, Marvel makes its most intimidating villain in Thanos, giving the audience a feel that this movie has real stakes, that he is someone to worry about, and that when he is on the screen, one should be scared of him. I found myself very intimidated, and was almost always fearful for people in the same scene as him. Easily one of Marvel's best villains.  I think that somehow the Russo brothers managed to do a wonderful job at presenting both entertaining characters, and making them feel real and believable. It's an impressive feat to bring so many characters from so many other creator's movies into this one, and to successfully capture their characters, and make their actions believable. I think it's absolutely incredible how well this was pulled off.  Something unsurprising the Russo's pulled off was the directing. The directing and action was good, having a more epic scale than the Russo's previous two films. This one feels more grand, the camera is often much more still than would be found in their previous two movies, helping the viewer to feel more grounded and presenting the world as larger. When important action scenes were going down, I was always invested. When important character scenes were happening, I was invested.  The music was very serviceable, and helped to elevate crowd-pleasing moments and get the crowd excited. I think this movie very successfully got my Thursday night crowd excited many times, there was a great deal of applause throughout the movie. This movie really is nonstop, with endless fun, action, some truly incredible moments throughout, and some genuinely shocking material. I won't say what they were, but many of my predictions going into this movie were wrong, and this movie was all the better for it. I'm glad I wasn't given the incredible task of making such a massive film.  It is of course worth noting that the story is great, it feels absolutely epic and the proper culmination of the last ten years of Marvel. Everything manages to fit together very well, and the grand nature of it makes it endlessly entertaining to watch. The story is most useful for seeing our characters struggle against seemingly impossible circumstances.  Above all, I find this to be Marvel's most daring film to date. A tone is set with the villain of this movie, and it is not an empty one. Thanos is intimidating and terrifying, I can't say that enough. While it manages to appropriately inject fun throughout the movie, it still maintains the scary nature of Thanos. He is intimidating, and his power really feeds into a true hopelessness that infected me, something the movie captures quite well. I do believe that some of the choices made in this movie are the most daring ones made in any Marvel film to date. I do believe that these daring choices, at least for the purposes of this film, were very successful.  Overall, this movie is impressive on so many levels. It succeeds in juggling a huge cast, balancing dark and fun tones, appropriately representing characters, having impressive direction, having fantastically crowd-pleasing moments, never ceasing to engage its audience, telling a great epic of a story, as well as being Marvel's most daring film to date. There was next to nothing I took issue with over this movie, and a great deal of stuff that I absolutely loved. I was very invested throughout the whole movie, and I genuinely don't think the film could've been much better. As I have said many times throughout this review, this movie is incredibly impressive. Naturally this review won't have any sway in your decision to see this film, as you most likely either already have seen it or are doing so in the immediate future. I still would like to offer this movie my praise, as well as give it my full recommendation, as one of, if not, Marvel's best yet.

...It's really hard to talk about this movie without giving everything or something HUGE away. What I can tell you is the bare basics of what you will be witnessing. And that is as follows: Everything you've seen, everything you know, is wrong. Your expectations are wrong. You are not prepared for what this movie has to throw at you. YOU'RE NOT. I surely wasn't; I found myself realizing my mouth was gaped open multiple times. Avengers: Infinity War is the cultivation of everything Marvel has built and it executed it almost flawlessly. There are only two flaws that can be found here. One, the pacing is a bit wonky at parts, as scenes cut away and tones can be shifted. Two, some characters don't get the spotlight that you might want them to. But these flaws are easily forgiven. As this movie delivers on EVERYTHING. The action is exceptional. The emotion is POWERFUL. The music by Silvestri hits you in the gut with every note. The story is at odds, taking turns in ways that you will never see coming, not even with clairvoyance. Now, I can't say much, but what I will say, is that Josh Brolin has given us, quite possibly, one of the greatest villains in cinematic history. He is scary, compassionate, charismatic, but most of all, empathetic. The Russo Brothers also directed their asses off and made their best work yet. That's all I can really say. You need to go into this movie blind like I did, because by the end you won't know what's coming next, you'll be speechless. So until the next Avengers movie arrives, I'll watch it, then watch it again, because it's the only movie we got for a while.
