STAR RATING: ***** Saturday Night **** Friday Night *** Friday Morning ** Sunday Night * Monday Morning The mighty, evil Thanos (Josh Brolin) is in need of one more 'infinity stone' to place on his giant glove in order to control the universe. In New York, Tony Stark (Robert Downey Jr.) is approached by Doctor Strange (Benedict Cumberbatch) and his ally Bruce Banner (Mark Ruffalo) in order that they reunite to battle him, and gets treated to a big demonstration of his powers in a massive city battle, during which young buck Peter Parker (Tom Holland) makes his presence known as his Spider-Man alter ego. As the old gang reunite, they cross paths with Skylord (Chris Pratt) and his gang... After an endless stream of singular Marvel universe entries where individual characters have faced their battles and revealed their back stories, directors The Russo Brothers have here decided the next logical step is to create a big, all out spectacle of a film, where the stand alone characters meet up with the Guardians of the Galaxy characters, and combine their powers to take down an epic super villain. It's no doubt something the die hard fans of the series will have been looking forward to, and will have been on the cards for a while given the huge box office takings. But, while it's as big a visual splendour as all the others, in the end it sadly works best only on a superficial level. The central plot is paper thin, and not nearly strong enough to sustain a movie of its length and scope. Not only that, it's also overly reliant on the viewer having an extensive knowledge of all the previous films, rendering it a benign mystery to anyone who's casually chosen to see it. The original Avengers Assemble film (now unbelievably over five years old!) managed to get all the featured characters to gel together well, but this seems over eager to examine all the characters back story and relationships with others, and all together here, there's too much to take in, in a plot that goes nowhere and drags on for far too long. Overlong, overblown and over-ambitious, this will end up over-whelming even the most ardent Marvel fan. It just about manages to succeed by being as colourful and visually exciting as all the rest, with dazzling special effects and thrill a minute action sequences. But this, sadly, is pretty much the best it has to offer. ***

Loki's arrival back in 2012, and Ultron's activation in 2015, both share a common characteristic that completely isolates Thanos. With Loki and Ultron, they both were building and establishing their attack, while The Avengers were doing the same with the extra mile of having to construct the safest form of defense. However, in contrast, Thanos has already built, structured and established his attack, while the now Non-Avengers have no idea what, when or how said attack will occur. If you understand that, I believe then, that this whole movie will fall into perspective. Thanos never made an entrance, he was always in the room all along. The Avengers were watching all the doors and guarding all the windows, from a threat that already was. From a threat that already had the keys. That is why Infinity War ended the way it did, and it was perfect. After watching this epic gargantuan of a film, I realized that Thanos HAD to win, for him to live up to who he knows he is. Who we know him to be. We, the audience and fans needed to feel true powerlessness and loss of hope, especially because Loki and Ultron failed in those pursuits, thus, Thanos HAD to succeed everywhere they failed, and Gamora further symbolized that terrifically. This was not The Avengers' movie, not by a long shot. This, was truly and utterly Thanos' exravaganza. The story, is sublime. Avengers: Infinity War was not perfect however. Far from it in fact. But, it was so massive, that its imperfections were like wrinkles on an old, Soul. This film felt rushed, but it wasn't. It was efficient, and productive, however, though that is an excellent approach for the most part for a film this huge, it also is a consequence, because it robs us of certain joys we would've loved to be immersed in. The visuals were too much of what we've seen before. Though they were amazing, they did lack a certain inspiration, and inspired moments are what we've come to expect from the MCU. The fight sequences too were not as infinitely impressive as they could've been, but they were great, with sprinkles here and there of absolutely stunning set pieces. There is so much to say about this film it's insane, from good to bad, and that is a good thing I suppose, because that means we will all be talking about this grand, monumental epic for a long while to come.  8.1/10.

Infinity War contends to be the best movie of the superhero genre ever made. The sheer feat of juggling such a massive cinematic universe and having he pieces land in place is something I would have thought impossible, yet having missed 4 of the 18 movies preceding it (missing Ragnarok was the biggest gap going in) the entire film still flowed incredibly smoothly. I am and know some real hardcore comicbook enthusiasts, and so will there will always be some squandered potential, plot elements that did not fire on all cylinders, or characters we want to see more of, but there are strikingly few missteps to pick out given the scope of this film's ambitions. The incredible number of characters, plot lines and events that fit in here rarely seems ponderous, helped by a script that is laugh-at-loud funny without sacrificing the impact of the third act. The strongest part of the movie is the villain. Thanos is scarily powerful, and from the very first scene it's clear that he means business. He is charismatic, intelligent, and, once he has the necessary power, pursues his goal with relentless determination. In another world, this movie should have been titled Thanos: Infinity War, because this movie is really his story. His performance and presence are more than enough to forgive his (one exception here) rather forgettable henchmen. However, would I have really wanted them to have more screen time at Thanos' expense? Hell no. In the end, this movie doesn't work if you haven't spent the time to watch previous movies. If you've read the New Yorker review, the author wastes a lot of ink spelling out "I haven't watched any of the other movies, so I'm confused and that is YOUR FAULT". Try watching Return of the King and then leave being mad at the movie for not explaining all the characters (again) for you. These characters don't evolve in this movie, because this movie is about the culmination of all their individual story arcs over the past 10 years. Will that leave some people behind? Of course, but that's the price of admission for a coalescing of a cinematic universe into one movie the likes of which has never been tried before. Aside: There are some reviews of this movie that are explicitly low because people think that this movie deserves a lower rating than their peers have given it. Retribution against fellow users of this kind seems silly, but there is at least one question raised relevant to the discussion: should fantasy movies like this be rated in the context of other movies of it's kind or should they be seen in the greater context of all cinema. Infinity War isn't as emotionally penetrating as Schindler's list, nor as artistically daring as Mother!, but these are the wrong expectations, at least to me.

The definition of Marvel is "to be affected with wonder and astonishment, as at something surprising or extraordinary". Disregarding puns aside, 'Avengers: Infinity War' is the perfect encapsulation of its brand's namesake, as feelings of sheer 'wonder and astonishment' is what I experienced while watching the film. 
Somehow the Russo Brothers have managed to create a huge cinematic event that lives up to all the hype. This is one of the best MCU films yet, and this isn't just because of its size and spectacle. It still uses elements of the Marvel formula, so to speak, which have worked so well before, being bombastic action sequences and humorous character interactions, and unsurprisingly dials them up to 11. But then, these elements are applied and seamlessly blended with a tone which isn't exactly dark, but definitely desperate, which brings about a larger sense of danger and consequence that has never been done in one of these films before. 
While there isn't much of a plot outside of trying to stop Thanos from assembling the Infinity Gauntlet, it's the character interactions I mentioned before that Marvel usually does so well that keeps the audience captivated. And somehow, the Russos, along with screenwriters Christopher Marcus and Stephen McFeely, pull it off so well. This film has a gargantuan cast, and it manages to combine the differing tones from the various franchises without feeling cluttered. The duo of Robert Downey Jr and Benedict Cumberbatch as Iron Man and Doctor Strange makes complete sense, as their wit, sarcasm and goatees create great potential for friction and disagreement. An enthusiastic and awe-ridden Spider-Man also tags along with them, and Tom Holland makes it seem he's constantly amazed to witness the events taking place just like the audience. The campy cosmic styles of Thor and the Guardians of the Galaxy mesh together exceptionally and undoubtedly deliver the best uses of comedy. And the majority of the cast from 'Civil War', along with a few other additions engage in an awesome climactic battle in the 'Black Panther' setting of Wakanda. Naturally, not a lot of these characters understandably go through much development, which was a miracle in itself to see in Civil War, but a few do. This being Hulk, Vision, Scarlet Witch, Gamora, and especially Chris Hemsworth as Thor, who has further transformed his once disengaging character until 'Ragnarok', to probably the best Avenger, who has the most legitimate reasons to be engaged in this conflict. 
But the best character is the big bad himself, Thanos. Josh Brolin delivers an incredible performance of this character, who has been built up and hyped for so many years now, and he completely subverted my expectations. He is not the loud-spoken, egotistic, emotionless monster that had been previously portrayed in his cameos, who seemed to lack any form of motivation outside of a thirst for universal conquest. Instead, he is now a soft-spoken, sardonic, charismatic but fearsome individual, who has surprisingly altruistic motives for collecting the Infinity Stones and using them for universal genocide, that actually makes reasonable sense. And because of this, he is faced with certain challenges that he has to go through in order to achieve his goals, which demonstrates the raw determination of this character that makes him all the more compelling to watch. Some of my personal favourite scenes were just dialogue between him and one other character, which effectively utilises Brolin's acting skills to show Thanos' more emotional and sensitive side, which I found more interesting, that overall creates what is probably the best comic-book villain since Chris Nolan's 'Dark Knight' Trilogy. 
The structural features on display are mainly on-point. Trent Opaloch returns as the cinematographer from the Russos' previous 'Captain America' films, but this time suitably cuts down on the shaky-cam techniques which work well with the grounded tone of those films. Instead, there is a naturally more vibrant and poppy colour palette unlike his previous dull and graded cinematography. And every shot which encompassed this is just simply gigantic, which fits greatly with the enormous stakes of the film. Alan Silvestri makes a welcome return as the composer, and while there aren't any memorable tracks outside of the recurring motifs from the first 'Avengers', the score as a whole is noticeably emotive and synchs up well with the majority of the scenes, which creates more of an aural impact than the forgettable background noise in 'Age of Ultron'. The visual effects are very impressive, especially the motion capture used for Thanos, as it effectively picks a lot of subtle facial expressions Brolin uses to perform, that make him seem all the more realistic. And while I'd say the CGI does not reach the levels of visual splendour shown in 'Guardians Vol. 2', for the most part, they successfully merge with the live action, and work as a major improvement over the PS2 graphics in 'Black Panther'. 
Despite my gushing, there are certain issues on display. I felt like the script allowed for characters to make choices and actions which were either extremely convenient or inconvenient so that the story could proceed accordingly without having to grind to a sudden, albeit logical halt. And being the nineteenth instalment in this cinematic universe, there are going to be obvious continuity errors, as I found some events in previous films, especially 'Ragnarok', did not lead into this as well as they could have. And I already mentioned the size of the ensemble cast, unfortunately, means a few characters are dismissed from having actual development, especially the other villains, Thanos' Black Order, who don't contribute much except interesting designs and opponents for the Avengers. But this is only Part 1, so I believe the few heroes who felt left behind outside of fighting will get more time to develop properly in Part 2. 
Thus, 'Avengers: Infinity War' epitomises how to culminate a cinematic universe with now a decade of history, which is not showing any signs of franchise fatigue. And yet somehow, it also manages to be a shocking, thrilling, grandiose event, where it becomes the prime example of pure popcorn cinema. This is why these films appeal to the masses, and so they should.

One can say that for ten years running the Marvel Cinematic Universe continues to amaze and their latest installment 'Avengers: Infinity War' is a constant reminder that these characters have leapt out of their comic book pages and onto the big screen. With an all-star cast of familiar names and faces gracing the screen like Robert Downey Jr, Chris Hemsworth, Chris Pratt, Benedict Cumberbatch, Scarlett Johansson, and many others, I couldn't fathom how much they went through to finally come together in one movie. Director Joss Whedon helped kick off two Avengers films in 2012 and 2015, but thanks to brothers Joe and Anthony Russo (Captain America: Winter Soldier, Captain America: Civil War) they've pushed it further with these established characters and have a story worth telling. With the Mad Titan Thanos (Josh Brolin) unleashing destruction in his wake to gather all the Infinity Stones that the heroes have kept safe in the past, it's up to the Avengers to join forces with the Guardians of the Galaxy to stop him at all cost. The Russo Bros. did an excellent job in directing and gathering all these actors who not only gave splendid performances, but had its audience immerse themselves into a whirlwind of triumph and tragedy. Compared to a few past MCU titles, 'Infinity War' had the right balance of both witty humor and drama blended well into the action that it didn't derail the story itself. It kept me intrigued and curious to see what its mythos and pathos can do. When the movie ended, it had me left speechless and with so many questions looming over what lies ahead. I've heard some complaints from some people I've met saying they didn't like it because it didn't flesh out all the characters properly, missing other notable heroes, or lacked depth in the film's story, but I beg to differ. Since this is only the first half, surely its second half will bring this story to a decent close. My only nitpick was indeed that a few other heroes didn't show, but that's okay since they could likely be saved for its follow-up. Compared to past MCU villains, I was intrigued with the directors' approach in making Thanos being more than just a typical power-hungry villain, but somewhat sympathetic as well. Music composer Alan Silvestri's underscore is a brilliant accompaniment to the most pivotal scenes too. To close, this movie is, by far, a culmination of Marvel's wide assortment of heroes raising the bar in their shared universe. Only time will tell on what more can Marvel dish out from here beyond this Phase Three. The works of Stan Lee, Jack Kirby, and Joe Simon are now more than just drawings on comic book pages, they are embodiments who've made their mark in cinema.
See this movie from the other side, and Thanos is never a normal bad guy, he had his point and his bottom line that he never crossed.

Well well well, look who decided to watch another superhero movie? It's here! Infinity War is finally here, after 10 years of MCU movies and over 20 years of fan boys waiting to see the mad titan on screen! This review is for dad's all over the world trying to find out what their children have been bugging them about. Let's get right to the point, go watch this movie. Want more detail? Here we go. This movie starts off extremely well, building up that dark tone which lasts throughout the entire movie. There are three teams. We have the New York team, which consists of Iron Man, Doctor Strange, and the Hulk. We have the Wakanda team, which consists of Captain America (who now goes by the name Nomad), Black Widow, Falcon, Scarlet Witch, Vision, and of course, T'Challa himself, the Black Panther. Lastly, we have the Space team, which consists of Thor and the Guardians of the Galaxy. These three lines have their own individual story lines, yet they all slowly start connecting together. Feel that the plot is moving a bit fast with all the jump cuts? That's normal, after all, this is a marvel movie, not Dunkirk. Let's tackle the simple question, shall we? Why is Infinity War so talked about? Well, here's your answer: Remember all those random marvel movies that kept coming out? Only so you, the parent, could say "Marvel has so many superheroes! All they need to do is to keep making movies of them and then they're set for life!" Basically, that's what happened. Infinity War has all those characters in it. Hence "the biggest crossover..." Up until this point, some of the characters have been in their own world, minding their own business, such as the Guardians of the Galaxy. There was no connection to the Avengers or anything throughout the two movies, which is why it's fascinating to see them interact with all the characters who HAVE BEEN interacting with each other. Haven't seen a marvel movie in a while? Are you absolutely clueless are what infinity stones are? Don't worry, this movie does an amazing job of putting together the little bits of knowledge everyone knows and expanding upon them. Here's another reason why this movie is gaining popularity: people are going to die. You heard it here first, well, that's a lie. Your child kept telling you that, so this is more like the 10th time? Most of the characters you have been with for the last few years meet their ends, and it's up to you to find out. Do I, the parent, need to watch this?: my father personally isn't in to superheroes very much. I, on the other hand, am. I own dozens of comics and know exactly how each character is the way they are. I drove my dad with me to the theaters each time a marvel movie came out, some he loved, some he didn't. Go watch this with your children, you'll have a blast! Violence/Gore/Sexual Scenes?: some kissing (it's what people do). As said before, people do meet their end, some quick and easy, and others slow and painful. Nothing your child can't handle. Although they might get emotional when some, specific character dies, nothing too much to be worried about. Conclusion: fill up your gas (even though it's reallly expensive), go down to the theater, and watch this movie. Not only will you enjoy it, your kids will enjoy it x10 more that they will bug you for the coming days, maybe even weeks. That's called parenting. I'm 15, what do I know about parenting?

It felt like a non-stop train on a mission to get to the next city, but it's being blown up, and there are people trying to rob it, and there are couples in different cars showing affection, but there's a brain surgeon on board that has the cure for cancer, and a family arguing over a patriarch's death, and another woman learning the truth of her adoption, and all these people trying to stop the train from being blown up, all while riding on the train, going 200 mph. The two things that Marvel movies have always been under criticism for are their villains and lack of stakes. Not only does Infinity War put those criticisms away, it takes full advantage of the gravitas of the comic book it's based on. I can't really imagine a better way that the MCU could have closed out a 19 movie arc, while also perfectly setting up the final (for now) installment next May. In one of the gutsiest and deadliest superhero films to date, The Russo Brothers have once again delivered a meaningful and thought provoking entry into the MCU. I don't know how they did it, but they managed to give all 30 something characters time to shine while also giving several of the big Avengers or Guardian related characters an impactful arc of their own. There are very minute pacing issues that perhaps some casual fans may take issue with, but for someone who has been with this universe from the beginning, I ate it all up. I'm not sure there are any directors who could have possibly executed this story as well as The Russo brothers did. As with Age of Ultron, I worried that the tone of the trailers (dark and serious) wouldn't really translate to the movie, as the MCU is known for its humor. Ultron was a very funny movie but it still felt like a missed opportunity to not have a little more emotional weight to that story. Luckily, Infinity War brilliantly balances humor, heart, and some serious sh*t that goes down in this adventure-heist-thriller.  Much like its comic-book counterpart, Infinity War follows Thanos (and it's largely his story) and his quest for the 6 Infinity stones which gives him the power to wipe out half the universe. How can you possibly give someone like that shades of humanity and an understandable motivation? Well somehow they did it, and when Thanos or someone else does things that bring the emotion out of him, it's some of the best sequences of the film. Most impressively, the Russo's and the writers figured out a way to pick up where we left each character while also making it fit into an Avengers story that needed them to more specific things related to a bigger threat. In other words, this film is driven by characters and not plot. As much as I love Age of Ultron, it feels more like a film that had their characters act based on where the filmmakers wanted the plot to go (i.e. Thor's quest in the middle of the film). Infinity War is far from that, and is clearly structured by filmmakers who still have stories left to tell in this universe. I could go on and on about specific plot elements, scene stealers, surprises, and the bold direction the film takes, but I decided to take a more vague approach to this review to not spread the spoilery thoughts that the internet has been filled with the past few days. In short, Infinity War is the most balls to the wall film Marvel has ever done, but still fills it with brilliantly quiet moments that made Civil War and Winter Soldier so groundbreaking. 10/10

Commenting about his fake deaths and his power in mischief, Thanos gruesomely kills Loki, sealing his death. Thor is left to mourn his brother and his people, afterwards Thanos destroys the ship and leaves Thor to die. 
All throughout the movie, the characters interact with each other and its nearly perfect how they talk and work together to produce such an amazing team. In a Lord of the Rings sort of way, 3 stories occur, 1 group on Earth, 1 chasing after Thanos and 1 making a weapon that can kill Thanos. In the eve of all the situations, 2 battles occur, one against Thanos, and one against his army and minions/children and those who were making the weapon (Thor, Groot and Rocket) join the battle on Wakanda. Meanwhile, the battle against Thanos reaches a point where the group is able to subdue him, Star-Lord unfortunately learns of Gamora's death and hits Thanos breaking the connection the group has subduing Thanos, with Spider-Man almost removing the Infinity Gauntlet. To our disappointment (in terms of good side winning), Thanos defeats the group and comes close to killing Iron Man but Dr. Strange cuts a deal, Thanos spares Stark and Strange gives the Time Stone to Thanos. 
It comes to rise. One final stone to retrieve, Thanos has 5 and is near invincible. He travels to Wakanda via space portal. The final stand is now here. Everyone with the will to fight tries to stop Thanos but no one can stop him, not even Captain America stopped him, and in return, receives a kick-ass sucker punch from Thanos. It comes to a close, all that lies between Thanos and Vision is Scarlet Witch, and she comes to a hard decision and destroys the Mind Stone (is that even possible? awesome!) and its all over. Thanks however has the Time Stone and is able to reverse time where he revives Vision and rips the Stone from his head, killing Vision. At last, he puts the final Stone in the Gauntlet and with that, he is truly powerful, powerful enough to wipe out half the universe with the snap of his fingers. But WAIT, THERE'S MORE! Avengers: Infinity War is latest installment in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, and they have taken an unbelievable and daring step with this movie. 
Kevin Feige and The Russo Brothers have cooked up a masterpiece, which will keep you at the edge of your seat, and when you least expect, it will send you into a state of denial.
An amazing quality of this movie is how unpredictable it is, and what an amazing job Marvel did and keeping the plot a secret until the release, by handing out fake scripts to the actors and whatnot. 
The special effects, and the CGI in this movie were better than any other movie of the MCU, nothing at all seemed unrealistic (except Proxima Midnight at certain parts of the movie.)
Another one of the best things about MCU's latest installment is that although it will be a completely different experience for Marvel fans (people who've watched the movies, who read comics and in a nutshell, know everything one's supposed to know for Infinity War) compared to people who're just watching the movie for the sake of watching such a hyped release, it'll still be pretty amazing for those non-fans. Because they've made the movie in such a way that even a person who knows very less will understand what's happening.
Another amazing thing was how they portrayed Thanos. They did it the right way. They made us see his emotions, his reasons for being a genocidal purple egg. MCU has done great with their villains in their past two installments; Thanos and Killmonger. With Hela they didn't really get into depth. And they didn't really show Hela as a person, they just showed her as a mad woman killing for fun and a hunger for the throne and power. But with Thanos and Killmonger, they showed us what they went through to have these motives and aims. They didn't show them as madmen, they showed them as people. Normal people, with normal thought processes, and the ability to feel, which in my opinion is the best thing you can do with a villain; make them as human as possible.
Now we get to the quality every MCU movie has; the humor. I think this might be the best Stan Lee cameo for me. And having this ambitious a crossover is difficult, very difficult infact, but they used humor to make the characters go together perfectly. Tony Starks sarcasm, Peter Parker's movie references, Thor not knowing what to say where and Star Lord's (hilarious) narcissism all mixed in perfectly acting as comic relief scenes. 
And the last of many qualities of this movie; the daring step and breaking the cliche. This movie is not like every other superhero movie, I repeat, it is not like every other superhero movie. It's the biggest Cinematic Event in the history of cinema. And that is for a reason, not just a very grand cast, but an amazing storyline. If you have seen it, you know what 
I mean, but if you haven't....then I guess you will.
As Thanos wants things "perfectly balanced", that's what they did with this movie; humor, action, climax and emotion blended into a perfect balance. 
One of the best movies of the 21st Century, for me.

Okay, misanthrope alert! In the case of Avengers: Infinity War, I found myself actually rooting for Thanos more than the Avengers. It seems Thanos is the only one who realizes that there are too many people and is actually doing something about it. No that I have that off my chest, what about the movie? 
As with the rest of the Marvel Universe films, there is no shortage of action and all your favorite characters are there. In that respect it feels like Pasta Puttanesca: You throw in whatever you have in the cupboard. And, for those of us who have not been totally sucked into the storyline, CNN has produced a good summary and timeline to help decipher the nuanced hints of what was to come in Infinity Wars. 
The writers have done a good job of interweaving the various storylines together, no mean feat, to keep those who, such as myself, have not followed the story arc over the pat 10 years. Visuals, as yo would expect are stunning, and the hand-held photography is kept to a minimum so as not to induce vertigo!
Infinity Wars certainly raises some major questions about what is to come. I mean how can you eliminate that many key figures and keep the franchise alive? But then, Thanos does have the time infinity stone, so who is to say that time won't be reversed. After all this is fantasy. 
The Marvel franchise is getting long in the tooth and personally, I lost much of the wide-eyed anticipation long ago. But Avengers: Infinity Wars does a lot to bring back the enjoyment of the franchise and left me with a "Say what?" at the end.

Even though it's not perfect, I must say that AVENGERS: INFINITY WAR totally delivers all you want from a MARVEL movie. It gives you: the characters you love, the villain you've been waiting for and, of course the action sequences you've been craving like a fist-shaped bar of MARVEL-brand chocolate! We ALL should know by now that Joel and Anthony Russo+ MARVEL MCU= greatness and INFINITY WAR proves that fact yet again! Overall it's a pretty cool and fun ride, but you certainly have to prepare yourself for typical superhero silliness. However, the silly superhero stuff is told in a mature, non-patronising way and it wasn't like the rest of the of the frankly "daft" superhero films of the past year. Yes, I'm talking about you, THOR: RAGNAROK, SPIDER-MAN: HOMECOMING, BLACK PANTHER and GUARDIANS OF THE GALAXY VOL 2. Though INFINITY WAR is certainly NOT realistic at all, it grips and has a serious tone that keeps you watching. The script is dynamic but also very funny in some parts and we get a good look at MOST of the characters. The plot is simple and nothing THAT new or fresh but it still grips and provides real closure on the already rather over-bloated MARVEL cinematic universe. There were a couple of elements I wasn't QUITE sure on but more about them later. Firstly, the good things: the plot, the characters and action. The plot for the most part was really exciting and really had me gripped; it was serious and tense. However, it WAS a little dull in some parts. There were a few times when things lagged for a while but on a whole I was never really bored during this film. The main thing I was concerned about in this film was the amount of additional characters and how the film could easily become convoluted. Here's the thing: it didn't feel convoluted BUT, some of the characters do get sidelined. Some of your favourites like Captain America, Black Widow and Black Panther were kind of pushed out into the background and though they featured, they didn't feature as much as some (and me) would have liked. The story really focuses on three sectors: Thanos, Team Iron Man and Team Guardians. Everything else is really not that major. Now, on to the action. The action in this film was quite frankly AWESOME! After all, these are the directors behind the elevator and airport fight scenes in the Captain America films 2 and 3. The battle for Wakanda plays out like a completely OTT version of the battle of the Pelennor Fields from LOTR 3 and once the infamous AVENGERS score kicks in, you know you've got a good thing going!  Now, on to the acting! Almost ALL the members of the cast are great and give it their all! Some of these characters may not get all that much to say but they're all well-acted. However, I REALLY wasn't sure about the movie's main villain Thanos (Josh Brolin). I must admit I found Thanos (as a character) rather bland. You certainly realise what a threat he poses to the Avengers but really, he's a purple Darth Vader who's not THAT interesting. Brolin's performance is strong as the genocidal maniac but there were times when Brolin simply read the script. Though the villain is something new, I don't see him as a cinematic villain that will stand out! On a whole, the film was fun, action-packed and gripping but it's nothing REALLY new and as my Dad so rightly said: "once you've seen one; you've seen them all!" The conclusion was devastating and raised many, many questions and the after-credits scene was certainly interesting even though it wasn't really worth waiting for. Definitely a fun ride but I couldn't really say that "this... Does bring a smile to my face"...

The sheer scale of this film made me sceptical of it at first. I knew I was going to love it being a massive Marvel nerd, but I did have worries about it feeling a bit over-saturated and disjointed, given the huge number of characters. Thankfully, the Russo brothers have pulled this off in almost flawless fashion. Each story arc is seamlessly blended together, while we focus moreso on the impending threat of Thanos, than any individual hero's story. This gives this film an incredibly different feel to the formula that we've grown to expect from Marvel, in that the single most important character is the antagonist, which subsequently means that he gets more development than anyone else. This is a more than welcome change if you ask me, as it serves as a good counter-measure to the lack of great villains in the MCU. Brolin breaks the tradition with his portrayal of Thanos, a super villain to which we relate in ways, who's point we see and last but not least - who feels like an ENORMOUS threat to the entire universe that we love. Just how much of a threat is very well established in the opening scenes. As the film progresses it jumps from character to character, or rather group to group, as separate teams each have their own parts to play in the upcoming showdown. This in no way damages the story-telling, and the Russo brothers deserve a huge amount of credit for how they managed to keep it so coherent, despite the events taking place across multiple planets, at the same time. Stylistically it does what every great marvel film does, it mixes a perfect blend of humour and action, becoming more serious when it needs to be... in moments that become more and more frequent the deeper you get. This film will make you feel every emotion you could imagine, especially if you're already invested in the universe and it's characters. It's worth noting that the chemistry between some of the characters that we've never seen together is nothing short of brilliant! Doctor Strange and Tony Stark clash, as do Stark and Peter Quill, The Hulk has some hilarious moments and Thor, Rocket and Teenage Groot make for a highly amusing trio! There are bucket loads of cross-overs here, as expected, each and every one of which makes for seriously entertaining viewing! I don't want to include spoilers in this review, but this film takes what we've come to expect, laughs at it, and does the exact opposite. As the title states, it's been 12 hours (more than that now) and I still can't stop thinking about what I witnessed in the cinema last night. I don't think anybody will be quite ready for the way it ends. It will leave you begging for answers and questioning everything. Be warned, you may leave the cinema emotionally drained, but you will leave more satisfied than ever. I rated this 10/10 but I don't really think any movie deserves a perfect 10. This is a 9.5 for me. Easily top 3 Marvel films of all time. Potential candidate for the best, and definitely up there with the greatest superhero films of all time.

Since everyone likely to watch this has already seen plenty of Marvel Comics' superhero movies, let's keep this one simple, with a good news-bad news format: Good - More superheroes appear in this one than you could shake Thor's hammer at. 
Bad - It's occasionally hard to keep track of who is using which power against which enemy or henchperson thereof.  Bad - It runs 2 ½ hours. Good - The action is so (dare I say?) fast and furious that it sure seems a lot shorter.  Bad - After all that time, the movie ends with a lousy situation, including some surprising deaths, just to set up a sequel.
Good - Since the power to control time is one of the themes, maybe the sequel will undo some of the losses we witnessed in this one.  Good - Stan Lee's cameo comes early, allowing focus to remain on the main story. Bad - What could possibly be bad about a Stan Lee cameo? They're always nothing but degrees of good.  Good - Josh Brolin looks and sounds suitably menacing in the role of archvillain Thanos, while also showing more emotional layers than usual for the genre. Bad - The handsome Brolin, in full regalia, bears a shocking resemblance to Ron Perlman, which would be a serious loss of points on the old 1-10 scale if carried over to his real life.  Good - Wonderful comic touches from Robert Downey Jr.'s Iron Man/Tony Stark and the crew from Guardians of the Galaxy. 
Bad - Much of the action occurs in such dark, ominous settings, creating the impression of DC Comics having invaded this universe. Even Darth Vader would have wanted to redecorate Thanos' spacecraft and environs top cheer the place up.  Bad - Dave Bautista's endearingly dense Drax is getting even dumber. Good - At least his form of stupidity is funny, unlike the same trend in the US Congress.  Good - Thanos' evil plot is to save all the planets in the universe that have become overpopulated by wiping out half of their populations in a single stroke. Since he offs them randomly, he thinks it's fair, making him the ultimate eco-warrior. Bad - See previous comment about US Congress, whose collective thinking is no better.  Good - Scarlett Johansson appears as Black Widow. Bad - She doesn't get enough screen time to display her lithe and lethal skill set to full advantage. Actually, the same pairing applies to lovable tree-creature Groot, but for very different reasons  Bad - The credits are really, really long. Good - The standard teaser after they finally roll past is worth the wait.  Good - Franchise fans (who, unlike me at the time, already know this isn't a one-and-done story line) should be delighted by the script and the overall quality of the production, including all the CGI vistas and mayhem. Go to the biggest screen and most enveloping sound system in driving range, since there's plenty of action worthy of those enhancements. 
Bad - If you've not already seen a fair share of the zillion movies or read a bunch of the decades of comics featuring Thor, Spiderman, Iron Man and all the other characters converging to defeat this epic threat to the universe, don't start here. You'll be a stranger in a strange land.  In space, no one can hear you bond.

This film should be impossible to get right. Gather over 30 characters from 17 other films, all helmed by different people with different visions, collect them and finish up the pay off that's been building for 6 years since our first glimpse at Thanos at the end of Avengers. The Russo brothers did it. They made it, and they made it spectacular. The action is satisfying, the character focus is laser precise, the story is taut with tension and a grounded battle against what is right, and what is necessary. Marvel has outdone themselves. Simply one of the best cinematic experiences of the century thus far. Detractors may point to under utilised characters, a reliance on CGI, and poorly timed humour, but when everything else is some of the greatest blockbuster action ever put to screen, to let those things bring it down would be silly.  If there was one gripe, it would be continuity. To fully appreciate everything in this film, you need to have seen Civil War, Doctor Strange, Black Panther, Thor: Ragnarok, Spider-Man: Homecoming, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol.2, and to understand those films you need to have seen the countless Marvel films before them too.  But for those who have seen it, for those who have followed Marvel over the last 10 years, here's to another 10. People call it oversaturation, I call it the biggest and greatest cinematic event to ever occur. Here's to you, Marvel, you've done the impossible. You kept the fans happy.

The story arc continues as "Earth's Mightiest Heroes" face Thanos, their most implacable and powerful foe yet, whose goal is nothing less than the elimination of half of the universe's denizens. To do this, he must acquire all six of the infinity stones, colourful MacGuffins with a complex metaphysical backstory - a plot device that allows for a series embedded stories involving subsets of heroes and villains. The story is quite good and relatively internally consistent, and the characters interesting and well worked out (although I have my usual suspension of disbelief problem with The Avengers somewhat asymmetrical powers: Black Widow knows martial arts and is a good shot, Thor is an immortal God who can fly though space and withstand the focussed power of a degenerating neutron star, yet both seem to get equal hero billing). Even the most heavy made-up (or completely CGI) characters have a lot of personality, especially (IMO) chief villain Thanos, emotionally-expressive Mantis, and my personal favorite: giant dwarf Eitri (Peter Dinklage). The script manages to hit a good balance of action/drama and comedy (tricky to do and often a weak point in the genre). The ending is a set-up for the next film, in which we can expect Captain Marvel to put in an appearance (perhaps a harbinger for the next generation of Avengers). Given the God-like powers of some of the heroes and the fact that Thanos can now control reality and time (always a convenient plot gimmick), pretty much anything could happen.

As the greatest threat the universe has ever seen seeks the six stones which allows him to decimate any living creature, the disassembled Avengers must do whatever they can, even if that means making the toughest sacrifices, in order to prevent Thanos from achieving his goal. This third installment in the Avengers franchise brings a different approach to the series. It gathers its very popular characters/superheroes and puts them in a situation they've never faced before. Threatened from multiple places and also working on multiple plans, their actions are now bound to bring drama, rather than joy. Thus, the much darker atmosphere this movie generates is a very welcome change at least from my point of view. We still get the awesome scenery and the deeply satisfying action sequences, but the drama which they tend to generate has a much bigger impact. We also get some laughs seldomly and even some interesting sarcasm which are a good addition to the film, but those are somehow expected from a Marvel movie. As you might have guessed by now, the plot represents the movie's greatest aspect. The way it unfolds and the way it generates such emotion is unique, thus you have to give it credit for that. The characters are very well known from the other Marvel movies so there isn't much to say about them, besides the fact that they keep their characteristics, both good and bad, and that they are very well played by their impressive and charismatic actors. It's needless to say that this movie's cast can easily impress anyone without even mentioning the title or the plot. The visual part is top-notch. You get such great CGI that you're eyes simply cannot believe what they are seeing. Everything is so well thought and implemented that you cannot avoid saying "wow" at least a couple of times. We tend to get accustomed with CGI and special effects these days, but the ones features here are simply extraordinary. In conclusion, it's so far the best movie which "wears" the Avengers name, bringing a new approach to the franchise while leaving plenty of room for a highly expected sequel thanks to its unpredictable but also very profound finale. It managed to impress in every single way so I give it full credit for that.

The Avengers, no matter which way you look at it is an incredible achievement. The 6th official entry in the MCU which was a multi million cinematic experiment 4 years and 5 previous Marvel films in the making for its eventual leadup of its iconic superhero characters became a critical and commercial success which pioneered the superhero crossover film, revived the superhero genre and rewrote pop culture in a way that is still being felt today even after its release nearly 7 years ago now. The overall genre and emotional tone of The Avengers along with every other modern Marvel movie with its near perfect blend between drama and serious storylines but with light hearted comedy and great action sequences. It's been able to get everyone together, not just the comic fans due to Marvel's now infamous MCU formula with its massively wide spreading and universal appeal to anyone who has any interest in Marvel superheros and being entertained by a light-hearted action comedy blockbuster which has proven time and time again to be right with every Marvel film since with the Marvel Cinematic Universe now becoming the highest grossing film franchise in history with over 1 billion dollars. Now with Infinity War out, the third and possibly final Avengers film. The formula is now starting to become tested. No Marvel film before Infinity War has really tried to be dark, but the MCU is changing and now after seeing the film and where it went emotionally and storywise and have no idea where it's going to go after the way it ended, which is good. Marvel has listened to fans complaints of how previous villains were not serious or intimidating enough and how no main characters have ever actually been killed off with the feeling that they might not ever come back, this movie changes all that. Infinity War is not predictable. It's surprising and entertaining in the first half, then it hurts you and leaves you cold. Thanos was an incredible and brutal in this film as was the type of villain that Marvel Studios really needed at this point and I think they did an incredible job with the character aswell as all the choices he made and all the things he did in this movie, he was a better villain than by any right he needed to be. His CGI was great as well. It's a lot harder to talk about this film in a review than you think, and what it means for the future of Marvel Studios apart from saying it's my favourite Comic Book film of the decade so far since The Winter Soilder and complete new milestone for Marvel. Not just for Marvel, but for Comic Book Films as a whole. The MCU will grow in new ways unlike ever seen before because of this movie, and I'm looking forward to seeing how Captain Marvel is going to do that. I have no idea what's going to happen next, I don't read the comics

Yes, this is a Marvel Superhero Movie. Many of the fan favorites are here. They are all doing what they are good at doing with their skill sets used for protecting the Universe. There are the fights, then the battle. Then they lose. They lose big. What? Yep. Why? Logically, how can they not? Logically, And that is the beauty of what is presented here. A bold move for beloved characters but it works. These Super Hero characters are faced to confront the inevitable. How can they combat an egotistical maniac with power who thinks he knows what is good for the Universe as he sees it --and knows if he can capture the five stones that (basically) represent a corner of each existence to do so? Nothing will stop him. He will destroy family, friends, Nations, Worlds to get what he wants. And gets it. That..is Thanos. (What..? Who'd you think I was referring to? If so, then maybe that's why the film irritates some, and saddens others. It takes you from fiction to a possible reality and that makes you..think). No plot? Really, it's the oldest plot in the world and presented here it is entertaining, but heartbreaking. Heroes win, don't they? Evil gets defeated, doesn't it within 2 1/2 hours with all your favorite Marvel Superheros at battle? This film starts with horror, and ends with it too. That is the beauty of this entry. Fans will walk away musing as things are left open (not unsolved). Fans also know that Thanos will not magically disappear and everything will turn out perfect. It didn't. It won't. Thanos is the part of the Marvel Universe you'd never expect to see in an entertainment film, but had to. And now is a good a time as any to do so. Iron Man, The Hulk, Thor, Captain America, Black Panther, Doctor Strange, Vision, Guardians of the Galaxy and all the characters that surround them are all here to battle to save the Universe. Universe. Big place. It was great to see them all on the screen, and as I've already mentioned, doing what they do best. The BEST part of it for me is seeing them act as teams to do so. But, they are battling a more than formidable entity no matter how much teamwork they try to overcome it. Hope? Well, that I won't spoil for you -- but let me tell ya, the Marvel Universe is HUGE, and this film only touches the surface of what else can be introduced. And one part of the MCU I've been waiting for, is strongly hinted to arrive, and I cannot be more happier to see it (in the next installment, I'd bet big, yes!). Will there be a happier ending there, maybe? Um, not sure. But that what makes this a great film -more than just a summer blockbuster, more than just a bunch of Super Heroes in the screen mulling around the Universe. It actually makes you think.

Avengers Infinity War was everything all Marvel fans have been waiting for. Thanos finally reaching our heroes and putting their strengths and weaknesses to the test. That's exactly what the Russo brothers did and what the cast gave us. Josh Brolin as Thanos is just the right amount of villain to make you hate his guts but right when you think he's finally shown some sympathy to our heroes he stabs us all in the back (or pushes us off a cliff) to make us realize that hummanity has created the best and worst of us. And that's all portrayed in Thanos. 
The core 6 (minus Hawkeye) so 5, are all there with all the new additions and they are are surprisingly entertaining, heartwarming, devestatingly sad, and everything we asked for, even in Star Lord who I never could fully connect with. (Kudos to Chris Pratt for showing he's truly got a soul and isn't a totally butthole).  Two complaints: not enough Wakanda! Not only was Black Panther a wonderful edition to the MCU, it had more likability than GOTG (1&2) and better characters and we were snubbed of that. Especially T'Challa and Steve.  Second: not enough build up to the return of Red Skull. Perhaps it was meant to be a surprise and it did surprise me that they went that route but for fans who didn't see Cap 1 or never truly followed along to the MCU, it left them confused as to who that was and why I was wide eyed at the scene. We could have gotten some kind of clue that he would return and how he might affect the future films and if he will ever interact with Cap again before Evans' contract ends.  Overall: one of the best Avengers films there is. Marvel Cinematic Universe films that is. Perhaps it doesn't top Black Panther for the year and Ant-Man 2 is certainly in third, but it holds its own and will forever be the movie that had us shaken to our core when the screen went black at the end.

"Avengers: Infinity War" does what no movie has done before: incorporate 40+ superhero characters into one epic showdown against a god-like villain. This idea may have seemed too daunting 10 years ago, but with the talent present and the previous success of the MCU to at least make a decent movie, "Avengers: Infinity War" delivers, and stands as one of the best MCU movies to date. The Russo Brothers prove to be the best directing force the MCU has to offer. They made Captain America good with "Captain America: The Winter Soldier" and brought the franchise to its high point with "Captain America: Civil War." They don't disappoint here and do a great job of integrating all three phases of the MCU. They deftly balance screen time allowing a lot of the characters time to shine. Though they definitely could've trimmed time with the more boring characters like Vision, Scarlett Witch, Gamora and Nebula. The Russo Brothers forte is with the character interplay. The superhero interactions are the highlight of the movie as their banter is very comical, eliciting nerdgasms galore. The Guardians are the funniest and arguable the best characters in the MCU. The cartoonish action takes a back seat to the abundant humor and witty interplay. The action scenes are mostly enjoyable and inventive especially with Doctor Strange's wizard portals. It's very exciting to see the Avengers use pop-culture references to solve their problems (i.e. Aliens). The problem is that there is still some cheesiness with the action (characters having small talk during huge fights, characters smashing into each other mindlessly). The aesthetic of the characters' costumes and the CGI battle scenes give off a cartoonish vibe. One would have to let their inner nerd carry them away for maximum enjoyment of the action. *Spoilers*
"Avengers: Infinity War" finally introduces the storyline of Thanos as a power player. Thanos isn't your typical I-want-to-rule-the-world bad guy. He presents himself as a reluctant father-figure willing to make the tough choice: to kill half of existence so the other half can live with their dwindling resources. Thanos does not see himself as a bad guy but as a liberator willing to make sacrifices for the greater good. Of course the Avengers don't see it that way. What results from the Avengers' and Thanos' showdown is something Marvel has not done before, nor anyone would think they had the balls to do.  Many of the common complaints regarding MCU is that the heroes are impenetrable and no matter how cool they make the action sequences look, there is still that lingering stigma that no one will die. This leaves the action to be without real stakes or compelling drama. But "Infinity War" changes it up here and has Thanos succeed in killing half the Avengers team off (a microcosm for humanity). This resulted in a shocking and totally unexpected move. But.... one problem. Some of the character deaths are probably gonna be permanent like Loki and Vision but people who died from vanishing are likely to come back in the next film after the Avengers figure out how to undo everything Thanos did. Even if certain characters stay dead, it's not like a whole lot of them will be missed (only Drax and the Guardians would be missed if they died). MCU has more films planned like another Spider-Man, Guardians of the Galaxy, and Doctor Strange sequels (all of said characters died in "Infinity War"). This all means MCU doesn't have the balls to kill off characters that will churn out more money. They may have fooled us for a little while but we know their tricks. Hopefully they prove me wrong in Part II. "Avengers: Infinity War" is the best Avengers movie and one of the best MCU movies to date. It's thoroughly watchable, funny, entertaining, and even has a few tricks up its sleeve. It's a movie too big to miss. To have this many iconic superheroes, big time stars, and outlandish cast of characters in one movie is a cinematic experience you cannot miss. Be sure to keep your expectations in check because this movie is still a Marvel movie at the end of the day. It is not as good as the IMDb rating of 8.7, which makes it a top 20 movie of all time. No way!

2 years ago, I watched Civil War and was positively wowed by it, much so that I became an undying fan of the MCU. The MCU is admirable for managing to build an almost 20-film franchise packed with great films all leading up to this movie. Story: The story (for those who don't already know) is about the Avengers teaming up once again to face their biggest threat: Thanos. The Mad Titan wishes to collect the Infinity Stones to bedazzle his Infinity Gauntlet and wipe out half of the universe. The story is extremely captivating with major surprises throughout the movie and one WHOPPER of an ending. Direction: My major worry about this movie was how they were going to keep track of several plotlines without it feeling convoluted. And miraculously, the Russos pull off such a juggling act almost perfectly. Some storylines do go on for longer than they should but overall, it never feels overwhelming. Script: Christopher Markus and Stephen McFeely have made a fabulous script with plenty of comedy and yet great dramatic moments. However, some moments do feel too melodramatic and one moment in particular was undercut by a joke but that might the director/actor's fault.  Performances: I can't make this too long (there are over 20 HEROES in this, ok?) but everyone does well. However, Thanos is on another level compared to the rest. Josh Brolin manages to intimidate you as soon as he appears on screen. A serious achievement for Marvel to create such a villain worth the decade-long wait. Other Elements: As for the other parts, the action is well-done with less shaky cam than previous entries in the Russo's MCU movies. Everything else is fine though. Conclusion: To conclude, Infinity War truly lives up to the hype, being an entertaining, funny and emotional blockbuster that can delight MCU fans and regular moviegoers alike. In the words of Kevin Smith: It's going to be a long year until Avengers 4...

So here it is, perhaps the most anticipated superhero movie ever + the 3rd Avengers movie to date. This time Thanos takes over villain duties + i have to be honest, during the 1st 10 mins of this movie i was unsure if he could cut it alongside Ultron, but i was proved wrong, he's as badass as they come. What i wasn't so unsure of in those few minutes is that some of the heroes might not make it, but to save from any spoilers, i won't say who or when.
 The plot for this movie is a simple one, but one that has been used for some great superhero movies and used here for best effect. It revolves around Thanos scouring the universe in an attempt to gather all the infinity stones and that means facing off with some of Marvel's greatest characters including Spiderman, The Hulk, Thor, Captain America, Iron Man and Black Panther.
 The Special Fx in this movie are stunning and the action scenes thrilling, particularly the last climactic battle.
 As for the heroes, Spiderman with his wit, Iron man + Dr Strange, who face off with verbal sparring and Thor, who is always worth watching, are the stand-outs and of course Groot is always a laugh. Surprisingly though, captain America and Black Panther who are so good in their own movies are a bit bland here and lost in the mass of characters this movie has.
 So on the whole there is a lot to enjoy here, but there is some down-sides, mainly in the movie's middle set, where the movie gets a little laggy + perhaps there's too many heroes, especially given that there is no point in the movie where all the characters share the screen at once.
 So is this the movie of the franchise, definitely not, for me, Thor; Dark World and Avengers Assemble have that accolade, and it's not the movie of the year so far either, that goes to Rampage, but it's still great popcorn fayer and has points where your jaw may drop so far it hits the ground....yes Marvel really did just do that.

Short and Simple Review by WubsTheFadger After 10 years of character and plot building, we finally get what we have been waiting for. Infinity War is a film of epic proportion that makes first Avengers film look like a small feat. Infinity War has a complex story filled with exquisite fight sequences, humor, and amazing characters. The biggest hurdle for this film was fitting in a lot of characters in only two and a half hours. Anthony and Joe Russo successfully give all the characters a fair amount of screen time and introduces use to the amazingly effective Thanos. The story is filled with emotional moments and has some power when it comes to the reality of Thanos' power. The acting is very good. Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth, Mark Ruffalo, Chris Evans, Scarlett Johansson, Don Cheadle, Benedict Cumberbatch, Tom Holland, Zoe Saldana, Chadwick Boseman, Karen Gillan, Tom Hiddleston, Paul Bettany, Elizabeth Olsen, Anthony Mackie, Sebastian Stan, Chris Pratt, and many others perform very well. Josh Brolin performs the best in my eyes. He plays Thanos who is extremely complex and is the second-best superhero villain I have ever witnessed behind The Joker. Thanos truly is the best part of the film in my eyes.  The pacing is perfect. Infinity War throws us into the action immediately and doesn't let up. The runtime is also perfect. There are a couple of things a didn't like in the film. Peter Dinklage's character looked rather foolish. His accent and the way his character looked made him seem fake. I also didn't like the Wakanda scenes. Their accents are extremely annoying, in my eyes, and some the characters in Wakanda are kinda cringy.  All in all, Avengers: Infinity War is a masterclass superhero film. It is the second-best superhero film ever made right behind Christopher Nolan's The Dark Knight. I truly loved it and I am really excited for part two. Pros: Intense, emotional, and heartbreaking story, good humor, amazing characters, very good acting, Josh Brolin as Thanos, Thanos being one of the greatest movie villains ever, great pacing, a good runtime, and how Thanos is a really effective villain throughout the entire film Cons: Peter Dinklage's character is and looks bad and most of the Wakanda scenes and characters are kinda cringy Overall Rating: 9.0

Avengers Infinity War, the film Marvel fans have all been waiting for since the first Avengers film came out in 2012, has finally arrived and it is safe to say it has lived up to the hype from the last few years. The Avengers, Earth's mightiest heroes, have returned this time teaming up with the Guardians of the Galaxy, Dr. Strange, Spider-Man, Black Panther and overall the largest ensemble of superhero characters the world has ever seen on film to defeat the deadly Thanos. The film is large in everything, scale, cast, visual effects, action, just about all one expects to see and as it progresses, it doesn't shy away from reminding audience viewers how large it is. The film's time length was necessary to establish it's story and it's characters correctly. That said not every one is a fan of films that pass 2 hours for issues concerning the story dragging on too much and too many characters to explore with not many receiving proper care. The Lord of the Rings trilogy is the best example of films that reach the 3 hour length of time that is necessary to explore all plot lines. That trilogy worked out for many audience viewers though many that try and replicate this formula rarely succeed to accomplish what Lord of the Rings did. Avengers Infinity War is 2 hours and 40 minutes long and for the most part it succeeded in what it set out to do while many may say differently, especially those who aren't the biggest fans of the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Disney has never been more the extravagantly triumphant corporation that it is today with all the brands and licenses they have the rights too and because Infinity War has turned a grand profit, earning an estimated $640.9 million at the worldwide box office it's opening weekend, the latter proves itself true.  This film is mainly about Thanos. For a movie based on the heroes the Avengers, it's really his film as it explores his character in deep more than the others. Some have complained that Thanos should have been developed little by little in past MCU films before this one, however Thanos doesn't disappoint. This is probably the film's strongest point. He makes Ultron and Loki look like preschool for the Avengers to face. The best thing about Thanos is what a complex villain he is. He's more than a world conquering doomsday villain. His character is incredibly complex to the point where you can't decide whether or not you hate him or love him. The visuals for him as well as his acting portrayal are phenomenal, the same cannot be said for many villain characters portrayed through the use of CGI/motion capture. Possibly the most interesting villain character aside from Loki, he is also undoubtedly the most powerful adversary any of the Avengers have faced, proving too great of a challenge for all put together. The entire cast were amazing to see all together for the very first time, even though some got more time on screen than others do. Particular highlights include Robert Downey Jr. as he continues to develop Tony Stark's character in his darker side, having been tormented since the first Avengers film happened all leading up to him facing his greatest fear. Zoe Saldana excels portraying Gamora's suffering from Thanos that has left her damaged all her life, a side to her that has never been seen before. Benedict Cumberbatch as Dr. Strange brought a powerful, stoic presence among the film's cast. He shares great scenes with Robert Downey Jr. and they are shown to have great on screen chemistry. The rest of the characters served their purposes uniquely in the film as well. Some provide more humor than others and some get more screen time, others get less. A film with this many characters can prove to be difficult with giving each their due screen time.  The last thing to point out about Infinity War apart from the acting and visuals are the action sequences. Probably some of the best we've seen throughout the franchise. The entire film is leading to one big inevitable war that does not disappoint. Every action sequence in the film from start to finish serves as a teaser for the upcoming battle that will determine the Universe's fate. Excitement and terror are the feelings you get when you're watching the fights as you're wondering what will happen and who will die. It is true that there are tragedies throughout; that said, people in the past have complained about Marvel continuing the habit of convincing the audience that characters die only to bring them back to life. Despite the fact that many of these actors have contracts with Marvel, some for up to five to six years, it is a truly bad habit the MCU needs to halt immediately. Yes tragic deaths of beloved characters may be tragic but sometimes characters who die need to stay dead to produce emotion. Be that as it may, Part 2 of Infinity War is set to be released May 3rd of 2019. It may be a long while though Ant-Man and the Wasp is set to come out this summer, Venom is set for the Fall so we'll have plenty of distractions from the anticipation. To conclude Avengers Infinity War is a spectacle on film that fans of the franchise up to this point will not be disappointed, including non-fans who can also enjoy the film. It will leave you itching for more.

First of all, one request: dear users, for years IMDB has been a film platform facing the movies critically. This gave unsuccesful movies the oppurtunity to shine worldwide. Before rating the movie, please take some time to think about how good it really was done. 10/10 doesn't mean just good and 1/10 doesn't mean just bad. There's a difference between how good the movie was and how much you liked it. For example, Jumanji is one of my favourite movies, since I grew up watching it so often, but it still is a mediocre to good movie and nothing more.  It was very difficult to make this movie good. You have very different type of characters and they had to put unfitting atmospheres together. Then you have the biggest antagonist, who was very passive in the former movies. In the end the most tough challenge was giving all the characters the spotlight. And all I can say is that the writers and the Russo brothers faced these challenges pretty well.  Pro:  Infinity War reacted to every former MCU film. It's truly impressive how they made all the movies relevant for this composition. After all, it didn't even feel forced. At this point I would like to suggest to watch every MCU film before this one.  You really felt how much the actors and actresses enjoyed their role. There's not a single actor who disappointed. But the real show-stealer was Josh Brollin as Thanos. The character didn't even feel like a CGI model and a big part of this work was Brollin.  They really created a classic villain with Thanos. There was a good balance between cruelty and transparency,  One specific event of this film created so much potential for the next sequel. It lowers the challenges they had to face with here. 
Contra:  The decision to not rely on a main character and give everyone equal spotlight lead to less character development, except for Thanos and Gamora. The plot only reacted to the past, but there wasn't much plot in this movie itself.  Some people say that this was a dark movie. What they mean is that it has some dark events, but there weren't any dark elements. No matter how much I like the marvel characters, I really couldn't feel for them. It's not because of bad pacing like in other movies with this problem. It's because the mood immediately changes to too much comedy. And yes, the humour was great. But it wasn't necessary and took out the time for the actual plot. There weren't useful extended dialogues. In Guardians of Galaxy the comedic elements had meaning for the plot, but here they barely defined the characters and had the only function of making people laugh.  The score for the Avengers was never outstanding. Unfortunately here it was even annoying. But also this is a result of too many mood changes.  In the end Avengers: Infinity War is a decent popcorn film. As a marvel fan you will like it, as a movie fan you might get excited for the next sequel. In the end the path of Thanos was the deciding factor, while 50% of the movie was wasted with too much comedy and fight scenes.
