This is the first MCU movie that I went to watch at the theatre.This long awaited movie created so much hype that even I could not resist the temptation of watching the endgame on a big screen.Being a long time marvel comics fan I was already well informed about the infinity gems(called infinity stones in the MCU) and of course The Mad Titan Thanos and his Black Order(named Children of Thanos in MCU).I am mentioning this not to brag my knowledge or something but because I felt that some scenes of the movie were really meant for the hardcore fans and my friend(not a hardcore comic fanatic himself) with whom I went to spectate this spectacle did not understand and enjoy some scenes to the extent I myself did.Anyway I would like to point out some pros and cons first. Pros :- 
1)The direction is really great.Directing an epic like this looked almost impossible.Managing the massive roster of this movie and making sure that it doesn't turn out to be a mess is commendable.The Russo brothers deserve a bow for their near flawless direction.
2)The CGI is near perfect as it always is with the MCU movies.The movie looked really vibrant and colorful.Thanos's CGI in the trailer was a bit disappointing but the final cut is way better.
3)The acting is really great especially Benedict Cumberbatch and Chris Hemsworth particularly stand out.I would even go on to say that they outshine RDJ in this one.
4)The references from the comics are the best part of the movie.The iconic snap of fingers scene from the Infinity Gauntlet series is directly taken which is a big treat for the longtime fans.Moreover, the falling of The Hulk into Dr. Strange's sanctum sanctorum and disassembled Nebula are reminiscent of the Infinity Gauntlet series except it was Silver Surfer who falls instead of Hulk in the comics.Even the farmer Thanos is taken from the aforementioned series.There are more of them but these are particularly worth mentioning for me.
5)The music is really great.Feels appropriate at all the places.Alan Silvestri gets the job done.
6)Finally a really great MCU villain.Thanos is one of the iconic villains of the Marvel Comics and the movie version does not disappoint.The entire story revolves around him and boy is he the one to watch out for. Cons :-
1)Editing is not up to the mark.It feels like some scenes are cut short unnecessarily and some are inappropriately stretched long.Some important characters do not get enough screentime.
2)Marvel should have taken a bit more risk this time.Something feels wrong all the time.We get to see the battles,the deaths,the emotions but nothing feels like groundbreaking.We get very few scenes where our minds are blown off.
3)Though the CGI is near perfect most of the times,the Children of Thanos does not look that great.They looked like Marvel's version of Steppenwolf from Justice League(in a very bad way).
4)Starlord loosing his temper and attacking Thanos despite knowing the consequences looks really stupid and selfish.The writers could have thought of something else here. I have read some reviews on this site and some of the points few people mentioned,felt inappropriate to me.I would like to mention some of them here and explain why they felt so to me. 1)A lot of people complained about no plot and character development which I feel is wrong.The MCU is a 10 year old franchise and most of the main characters have had their own solo movies.The plot of this last battle has been developing for 10 years now and there really isn't much left to develop except well......the battle itself.
2)Killing off some important characters looked unnecessary for some people because many of them will eventually come back as they have their own upcoming solo movies.But this is what actually happens in the comics and trust me,you can not bring people wiped out from the reality by just using the time stone as suggested by some people.What brings back those people in the comics I will not reveal here but if that is anywhere near what is going to happen in the next part,it will be EPIC.So I am not at all disappointed with the ending.It just increased my expectations with the next one. Anyway I never expected it to be a classic or something and neither it is.It is a really great popcorn movie and surely worth a watch. PS:-The place where Thanos meets Gamora after wiping out half the universe may possibly be the soul world!!!!!!!! Have a nice day............

This film does justice to the characters, the cinematic universe, the source material, and most importantly, the fans who've supported the MCU and have been waiting for this specific story to begin to unfurl. It's a THRILLING cinematic experience. The first part of a five hour biblical epic in the skin of a galactic comic book space opera. This is studio film-making on the narrative and production scale of Peter Jackson's Middle Earth movies and old studio epics like Ben-Hur, Cleopatra, El CID, and The Ten Commandments (only with loads more CGI).  Selfishly , I only wished that the story could somehow have been presented in all of its five hour glory. Truth be told, I hate having to wait another year for its conclusion.  But anyway, here's a spoiler free summation of my thoughts: The plot of the movie is pretty basic: Thanos comes to earth and a bunch of other planets in search of the stones needed to assemble the Infinity Gauntlet. The Avengers must stop him. You already knew that. But the execution was nearly flawless. Marvel studios and all the filmmakers did an amazing job of making a very coherent storyline from the countless characters and threads the movie had to weave together and converge with Thanos, played with fantastic intelligence and subtlety by Josh Brolin. Thanos isn't you typical mustachio twirling scene chewing bad guy. He's surprisingly quite and sensible giving him a really calm, almost Hannibal lector like sense of menace. And he looks great. Actually all of the actors in the movie, namely the heroes, gave solid performances. But the real standouts for me were Chris Hemsworth, whose really has come into his own in the last year as Thor, and Benedict Cumberbatch as Doctor Strange. Those two characters have some of the best scenes in the movie and have some of the best repartee. On that note: The humor in the movie mostly fell flat, even when it was amusing. The stakes of the movie were just way too big, the tension just too high, for me to laugh. But that's just me. The action sequences were freaking phenomenal right from the gate. This movies action does NOT disappoint. And the movie doesn't go cheap with Thanos fighting...I'll just stop myself right there :)
What was much less exciting was the action involving Thanos' henchman. But that may be due to the fact that the filmmakers were very inconsistent with there power level and the power level of some of the other Avengers in the numerous fight sequences. Nothing takes me out of an action scene quicker than when characters who've I've seen portrayed on film, in some cases numerous times, have their powers nerfed or juiced up. In movies, like an many other things, consistency is key. But again, that's just me. Now...at this stage I don't think mentioning that there were casualties is a spoiler. But i won't get into specifics, either in terms of a number or a name. What I will say is that even if you're a casual MCU fan like I am, and you've seen all the movies, nothing will, or at least should, shock you. The biggest shock is in the way the filmmakers handle the key moment in the film... its darkest hour so to speak. That small moment, one simple action that was cleverly set up throughout the film, was incredibly poetic and haunting. I'm not lying when I say that you could literally feel the air leave the theater when it happened. Absolutely splendid. Made the movie for me. What followed in the last five minutes or so was a mix of good and okay. Nothing surprising to me. That's really where the fact that the movie is only part one of a larger story came back to hurt my enjoyment of it. I would also say that the nature of Thanos' goal, which I won't spoil, also played a part in that. The movie tried to tug on my emotional heart strings but the loss Thanos inflected on the heroes simply didn't cut close enough to the spine of the heroes to really make me feel anything. I'm dancing around this point but in general, the better you know someone, the more you're emotionally invested in them, and the more it hurts when there gone. I'll leave it at that.  
I'll close with stating that if your even a casual MCU fan you'll really enjoy Infinity War. It's a magnificent big screen sci-fi/space opera epic...just don't expect it to give you closure or really big emotional payoffs. Infinity War is as stated at the start, a part one film...and a damned good one at that. It's thoroughly entertaining and brilliantly sets the table for what promises to be an even grander Infinity War Part II... I mean Avengers 4 ;)

It was meant to be like that, to exhaust you until the last minute. On the other hand, there were too many characters but each and every one of them is shown equally with an enormous dynamic for all of them. Also, the scenes that were running simultaneously were masterfully crafted to fit in the story so that everything can end up the way it ended. 
Yes, there were many deaths and many of those deaths made us cry and made us emotionally unstable. But this is the movie, a movie about the possible end of the world. 
Thanos is the best villain that Marvel ever created. He threw Killmonger out of the window. We've seen an extraordinary part of his character. He is not the bad villain that everyone was waiting for. We've seen his good side in many perspectives, his only love. But we've seen what he is capable to do to accomplish his mission.
At last what Avengers: Infinity War has that no other superhero movies has is that ending. Those 10 last minutes that will haunt you forever and you will never forget them. Things take an unexpected turn at those 10 last minutes that you are not only left speechless but you leave the theater with your mouth fully open from surprise and your legs shaking from disbelief. 
It's of course the first part of a two part movie because it leaves you with an enormous cliffhanger but let's not forget May 2019 is not too far away from now.
Thus, this movie is a must see for all the marvel moviegoers and fans but also for people that have some knowledge on the movies background story. The cast and crew of this movie deserve a big applause and an enormous bravo from the entire world. I cannot believe that I've lived to see this movie. Infinity War is the nineteenth movie in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, so it makes sense people expect nothing else than the same characters fighting and joking. However, this movie is so much more than that. This isn't just a typical Marvel movie. This movie brings together 23 superheroes and concludes 18 previous installments to lead to the ultimate climax: a battle with the greatest and strongest villain of all time, Thanos (who raises in my opinion to the same height as iconic villains like Darth Vader or Voldemort). Thanos is more than a villain: he is a titan with the sole purpose of making the world a better place, only in the complete wrong way. Josh Brolin delivers an astonishing performance of this character and puts more to him than just a baddy, and makes him to someone who actually cares. 
As for the superheroes, Joe and Anthony Russo perfectly managed to give every single one of them a moment to shine. Special credits go to Robert Downey Jr, Benedict Cumberbatch, Zoe Saldana, Elizabeth Olsen, Chris Hemsworth and Paul Bettany.
The movie gives us not only a ton of humor, but also some memorable though heartbreaking scenes which puts a different tone to the film than all the others. 
There is a strong build up with some spectacular action sequences (where the heroes are divided into smaller groups so that every person has his time to shine), and the film ultimately leads to an epic and amazing climax with an unexpected ending. Well done Marvel.

I enjoy the whole Marvel comic universe thing they have going on now as to me having beloved characters I have seen in the comics and were a part of my childhood on the big screen is simply amazing. Then, like a comic book, I can be watching one characters film and another hero can appear. I loved crossover comics and I love crossover movies as well! This film features several comic book characters and Thanos, whom I have been anticipating in a Marvel movie since they teased him in the original Avengers film. I was disappointed a bit by the second Avengers film (still enjoyed it overall) as they went with Ultron as the villain and then later got more disappointed when I read somewhere that the Abomination was originally going to be in the film, but they scrapped the idea. That would have really given that film the kick it needed. This one though was not a disappointment at all as I got to see Thanos be as totally awesome as he is in the comics and I got to see many of my favorite superheros on the big screen at the same time! The story has Thanos, the mad titan, collecting infinity stones as he makes quick work of both the Hulk and Thor! The Asgardian ship seen in the previous Thor film is decimated as Thanos collects yet another stone and soon sends his children to Earth to collect the stone within Vision's forehead and the one protected by Dr. Strange. Thanos, himself, goes to the collector to retrieve the stone left in the Collector's care. Tony Stark ends up getting a warning from old friend Bruce Banner who gets back to Earth thanks to Heimdall and soon the children of Thanos make their attack as Tony must once again don the Iron Man armor to fight off these attackers and try to protect Dr. Strange's time stone. He gets some help from his friendly neighborhood protege, but all three end up on the ship of this weird dude who has very powerful telekinetic powers. Bruce Banner is left on Earth and he makes the call to Captain America who has to try and hold off the hordes of creatures that come for Vision's stone and does so by going to Wakanda where he will get the aid of the Black Panther and his old friend. Meanwhile, the Guardians of the Galaxy recover Thor and soon Thor, Groot and Rocket go to a place where Thor can get a powerful weapon to fight Thanos, while the rest of the Guardians try to stop Thanos at the Collector's. The power Thanos wields though is truly terrifying and things keep becoming vastly more difficult for all the heroes! The thing I enjoyed most was seeing all the different heroes interacting together. I was not expecting Dr. Strange, Spider-man or the Guardians to be in the film as much as they were. I was expecting more like extended cameos. I enjoyed watching Iron Man and the group on Titan fighting Thanos as they did a really amazing job of combating him. The only thing I wish there was more of is Captain America as he just did not really factor into the movie much at all being a bit ineffective. I also want him back with his regular shield too! Still, just a minor complaint in a movie that completely wowed me for the most part.  So yes, this was a very good comic book movie. I do believe I enjoyed it more than the first Avenger film which I also loved as this one was just so overwhelming and did so many cool things. This one also featured the best villain in Thanos, who they did really good with, making him almost sympathetic at times. The action was great in this one as all the battles were totally off the chain and as I said watching Dr. Strange, Iron Man and Starlord together on the same screen was simply great. I look forward to the next Avengers film coming thankfully next year. At first I thought it was not coming out until 2020, that would have been a very difficult wait!

Marvel Studios has over the years come under criticism for its lack of great villains in their movies. I'm not sure I totally agree with that assessment as I always thought Loki was pretty good, and Michael Keaton's Vulture in Spider-Man: Homecoming I really liked, I have to say. The Winter Soldier was another great one I reckon, as was the Red Skull. But I guess I can see where people are coming from with regards to some. Thanos however, more than makes up for any villainous shortcomings in the MCU. He wields awesome power with his nefarious intentions, but Marvel also manage to give him an incredible depth and intriguing method to his madness in this latest confluence of superheroes from all over the universe. We've known Thanos has been coming big time for a number of movies now and in this latest blockbuster he arrives with a bang. Or maybe more with a click of the fingers. Anybody who knows anything about the mad Titan and his skullduggerous designs on the universe in the comic books knows that that is pretty much all he has to do to achieve massive genocide on a galactic scale once he gets all six of the Infinity Gems in his gauntlet. Can Earth's Mightiest Heroes the Avengers, as well as a number of others and Galaxy Guardians stop him? Well, like many others over the record-breaking opening weekend, you will have to go and see the movie to find out. Of course, the movie technically comes in two parts even though the second instalment is not going to be 'Infinity War part two' as originally announced, but rather named something else. A title that was apparently held back because it might have spoiled certain aspects of this movie. It's never going to be easy incorporating so many different characters into one film - many of which who are pretty big in the comic book and movie world already - but following previous success with The Winter Soldier and Civil War, the Russo brothers pull this off again to great effect. This movie does jump around the universe a lot from scene-to-scene, but has a very interesting ending indeed. And for god's sake, unlike many others who still appear to not have cracked the code yet, make sure you stay for the post-credits scene. Because if you know anything about any of the characters in the spacey world of (Captain) Marvel, the next couple of movies in the on-going saga are going to be a real treat. Make mine Marvel!

Last night I went to the cinema to watch "Infinity War" and I wasn't thrilled at all. I'm aware that it's partly my fault, but anyway I think it's extremely overrated. Seen by itself, the film is completely meaningless, because this is not a stand-alone film, but the grand finale of all Marvel films that precede it. So, it's not just recommended that you have seen most of Marvel films before, but it's absolutely necessary that you have seen them all and that they are fresh in your memory. I watched most of Marvel films, but some of them I skipped, and many of those I did see I saw too long ago to remember them, so "Infinity War" left me with the impression of a bunch of amazingly shot, but empty action scenes, without the story that gives this action a meaning. It's like if you watched the last hour of "The Return of the King", without previously watching the rest of the trilogy or reading "The Lord of the Rings" ever before. Most movies have a part that introduces you to characters, then introduces them into a story, then develops and elaborates the story, and ultimately takes you through the blow-away finale. This whole movie is one huge finale, while all the other elements that you need to experience this finale right way need to be found in other Marvel films. Each of the previous films brings new characters, introduces you to them and connects them to the characters from the previous films, builds their mutual relationships and portrays small parts of the big picture, and then "Infinity War" puts all these characters together and, assuming you already know who they are, what their relationships are and what was happening in their individual stories, it immediately cast you right into two and a half hour of action madness, without any characterization and explanations, and with a minimum of the story that serves just to separate the action scenes. Marvel films are a literally series in which the episodes are somewhat independent, and this is the last episode, and do not even try to watch it if you didn't follow entire series. Although visually excellent, to me "Infinity War" was terribly confusing and even boring, and I will refrain from rating it until I see all the movies that precede him, and then repeat it with good background.

GRADE: B  THIS FILM IS RECOMMENDED. IN BRIEF: A superhero movie with a puny and weak plot and non-stop action. JIM'S REVIEW: Superheroes. They come in all shapes and sizes, with varying super powers and enough attitude and skill to fight against evil and protect mankind. More importantly, they rake in millions at the box office. The DC Comics and Marvel universe have taken over the movie business and offer critic-proof blockbuster after blockbuster for the insatiable moviegoing public. But perhaps my favorite crusader comes from neither source. He's a little big man by the name of Buzz Lightyear whose famous catch phrase and mantra was..."To infinity and beyond". That classic line may be over two decades old, but this toy oracle saw the future of cinema back in the mid-nineties. Which leads us to the 18th film from the Marvel Studios series, Avengers: Infinity War, the latest pop entertainment from one of the most successful and profitable franchise in cinema history.  In this installment, we discover that there has been a rift among superheroes. There is Team Ironman and his loyal crew of major and minor characters (Thor, Spiderman, The Hulk, Doctor Strange) versus Team Captain America and his colorful line-up of rogue groupies (Black Widow, Vision, Scarlet Witch, War Machine, White Wolf, Winter Soldier, Black Panther, Falcon), plus the Guardians of the Galaxy crew. Lots and lots of superheroes with little time to spare for deeper character development but lots of time for CGI and action stunts. Yet what will unite them all? Why, of course, a truly bad villain, namely Thanos, who wants all six of the magical infinity stones in his possession in order to dominate the world! (Maybe, collecting trading cards of all of the assembled superheroes might have been a more challenging goal for our conflicted outlaw.) Yes, the plot is puny and weak, but the consequences to stop this megalomaniac are of the life and death variety. So all you need to know is that the battle lines have been drawn over the prized McGuffin, with one battle scene leading to the next for maximum enjoyment. ACTION is in not in short supply, even if logic and high drama take a backseat to the frequent combat sequences.  Anthony and Joe Russo ably direct and keep the pace at warp speed lest they disappoint their youthful target audience. A screenplay by Christopher Markus and Stephen McFeely juggles the misadventures on the different planetary destinations with varied results, some are simply more interesting than others. To its credit, it establishes many likable quirky characters and their camaraderie is infectious due to the actors' personal stamps on their recognizable roles. Yet the movie has a hard time spreading its narrative with a balance of equal screen time and does little to advance the development of some central characters and their interrelationships. Too often the numerous sub-plots and mini-expeditions with such a large ensemble wears thin. Dialog has some clever humorous retorts but rarely aspires to any real poignancy or gravitas.  The gangs all here, with an all-star ensemble that includes Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth, Mark Ruffalo, Chris Evans, Scarlett Johansson, Benedict Cumberbatch, Don Cheadle, Tom Holland, Chadwick Bossman, and in lesser roles: Paul Bettany, Elizabeth Olsen, Tom Hiddleston, Anthony Mackie, Sebastian Stan, Chris Pratt, Zoe Saldana, Benicio del Toro, and others too numerous to name. Josh Brolin effectively plays the evil Thanos and creates a strong adversary who allows power to corrupt his soul. The CGI is impressive throughout. Less effective is the editing and handling of transitions. At times, the well staged combat scenes intercut some of the action. Too much planet hopping interrupts the overall flow and gives the film an episodic vibe...the sum of the parts never making a very cohesive whole. Yes, there is much to hold one spellbound with its big budget cast of thousands approach and the film's fine production values, but all the rigmarole and commotion almost exhausts the moviegoer rather than enthralls. One eagerly awaits for the fractured teams of heroes to meld into an unstoppable force, but it never truly materializes and the cliffhanger ending is far from satisfying. This long and epic film literally comes to a stop with no clear denouncement, taking Mr. Lightyear's phrase and deciding not to settle anything soon, just looking beyond...to the next installment, with no end in sight. In Avengers: Infinity War, the war rages on and on...and the Marvel franchise lives long and prospers...to infinity.

I'm really mixed to positive on this one. It's hard to explain my feelings about the movie without spoiling it, so I'll say this: the things that this movie does well, it does it REALLY well. Thanos was great as villain (his motives, not so much), the action scenes were good, I liked most of the character interactions, there were some emotional scenes that were done well, and a few things will transpire that you won't see coming, which was very exciting. After Thor's last atrocious solo outing (Ragnarok), I didn't really care much for his character but this time around, the Russo's brought the thunder (pun intended); he was my favorite of all the Avengers in this film (even though there were some still some residual Ragnarok traits, I'm willing to forgive them). The things that it does bad, it does REALLY bad. A lot of the humor was contrived; some of those emotional/dramatic scenes were ruined by poorly timed jokes, something that Ragnarok and GotGv2 suffered from immensely. Towards the middle of the film, the scenes seemed to kind of jump all over the place but that's just a small nitpick on my part. Certain characters were handled in a way that really bothered me, but I can't divulge on that point without spoilers. Lastly, the ending just fell flat for me; I understand what they were trying to do with the ending and it DID work to some degree, but for everything that happened in the movie and for it to end the way it did...it just didn't sit well with me. Overall, I thought the movie was good...the Russo Brothers are excellent directors (Winter Soldier is still, by far, my favorite MCU film) and I'm ready to see what they have in store for Avengers 4!!! 3.5/5 Stars

Not unlike the comic Thanos Quest, this movie is about Thanos manipulating his way into godlike power, until his power is cemented enough to put himself amidst the action. Besides being a brilliant, tactical, philosophical being, Thanos is also in pain because of the terrible choices he has to make. This movie is not just about Thanos' battle against the heroes, but the internal quest he has to make, to fullfill a destiny. That's why it's easy to forgive this movie for the lack of character development among the heroes. the relation between Wanda and Vision, Wakanda, the motivations of the Children of Thanos etc. Everything and everyone is little more than a stepping stone for Thanos. But with a character so well written, Thanos deserves nothing less.

It goes on a little long, and towards the end the action becomes a little bombastic, but overall it's tremendous fun. The movie also, like The Empire Strikes back, ends in the middle. I really hate that. I also feel it telegraphs the next movie. I mean, you really can't engage in such wholesale slaughter without the assumption that in spite of all odds something will be done, and this blunts the emotional impact of the whole thing. Is the resolution to this movie really so elaborate that it requires it's own movie? Couldn't the bloat and some of the nonsensical plot extenders (like a blindingly stupid and unlikely moment from Starlord) have been removed to make a single zippy film? Probably, but that's not what happened. Alas.

What started as a risky gamble from Marvel Studios in 2008 with "Iron Man" has turned into a 10-year journey of character development, adventurous stories, and the most lucrative film franchise of all-time. The Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU) has been building to a gargantuan culmination for a decade, and that pinnacle is Avengers: Infinity War (IW), a generational milestone in filmmaking, an ultimate assembly of more-than-established characters, one of the greatest superhero films - one of the greatest action/fantasy films in history. For the first time in one of its films, Marvel Studios thrusts its primary villain to the forefront, as the Mad Titan Thanos, the definitive big-bad of the MCU, takes center stage, and in doing so, cements himself as one of the greatest comic book-film villains ever to grace the screen. Thanos has a wickedly sadistic goal, to eradicate half of life in the universe using the six Infinity Stones, which have been meticulously placed throughout the course of the MCU's history. Yet, his motives are understandable in a horrible way, he has the capacity to love and care, and it gives something to latch onto the character besides him being a psychopath for psychopaths' sake. His sacrifice of Gamora is the definition of his complexity, it's an emotionally taxing scene and one of the film's best. The big purple baddie is given the most screen time of any character, he's developed properly and given immense power over our main heroes, creating a massively intimidating villain who presents very threating stakes. To top it off, actor Josh Brolin is simply brilliant in his motion capture role, and Marvel made sure to put the finest details into making Thanos look believable, not making the same mistake Warner Bros. did with Justice League's Steppenwolf monstrosity. Infinity War's narrative isn't afraid to demand your respect right out of the gate, setting the tragically dark tone by showcasing its Everest-level stakes with the deaths of long-standing franchise characters Loki and Heimdall. Not to mention Thanos gives Hulk, the strongest character we've known in the MCU thus far, the beating of his life to solidify the fact that IW, Thanos and his Children mean business. The heavier tone echoes through the 149 min runtime; we see beloved heroes desperately fighting to survive Thanos' galactic onslaught, plot twists that barely allow you stay in your seat, chillingly gripping dialogue and an ending so Earth-shattering it would break the Richter scale. The decision to have Thanos win (albeit temporarily), to kill off numerous fan favorite characters in the blink of an eye, it's a finale like no other, a gut punch of the highest level. And even though many of the deceased characters will return, their deaths still leave an immediate impact, and a message that Marvel isn't always a Saturday morning cartoon. Even the end-credits don't roll with a glorious artistic montage as heroic music booms in the background. Here, it's somber string instruments with black and white text. After 2017 was packed with comedic-heavy Marvel entries, it was wonderfully refreshing to see IW take itself as seriously as a comic book story of this magnitude could. Fitting the crazed Mad Titan into a compact story with over two-dozen other main characters seems like an impossible task. Alas, the masterful vision from directors Joe and Anthony Russo, (already praised for creating arguably the previous two best films in the MCU with "The Winter Solider" and "Civil War") along with the magnificent lettering of lead writers Stephen McFeely and Christopher Markus, create a story on a scale never before seen in cinema, making it as well-paced and compact as possible without creating a 4 hour film (which many fans, myself included would love) and then tying a pretty ribbon on top. What allows Markus and McFeely to have the confidence to create such a jam-packed film? The pure notion that there is a 10-year foundation of profound character development to build onto. A story of this size could never work if it didn't have beyond-established characters to work with, which is how new ones are able to be introduced in this film as well. That includes Thanos and his four Children, Ebony Maw, Proxima Midnight, Corvus Glave and Obsidian Stane, all who add tremendous layers of depth to the antagonistic side, none more than Maw, who is often a scene stealer. Seeing all these characters in the same film is unbelievable, truly. And what's more is that every distinct trait found in every character is fleshed out and often creates down right epic or hilarious moments. Going off an earlier point, while the tone of IW is without a doubt more mature and gritty, there's a presence of humor that rivals the likes of Guardians of the Galaxy and Thor: Ragnarok. And since those films' characters both can be found here, along with several more, IW becomes one of the funniest movies in the MCU. Along with heroic moments and entrances that just make you want to stand up and cheer, it's a perfect supplement to prevent the film from being a in a constant state of depression, making all the characters as enjoyable to watch as ever. If you want blockbuster action, look no further. Infinity War flexes its action-muscles bigger than Hulk's to display ridiculously entertaining action sequences. The combination of heroes never before seen on the big screen together paves way for grand flashes of next-level action, it's dazzling to see the likes of Iron Man, Doctor Strange, Spider-Man and the Guardians all take on Thanos while Black Panther and company fortify the glorious city of Wakanda from an invasion to retrieve the Mind Stone. A sweeping score from Alan Silvestri (The Avengers) stands out and adds to the drama. Its majestic mayhem, fueled by stunning VFX, moving set pieces and captivating atmosphere, all gelling together to form an enthralling superhero spectacle.  To be short but sweet, the acting department of every single character is unparalleled in today's superhero genre. There's simply too many names to list off, but MCU icon Robert Downey Jr. (Iron Man), Tom Holland as Spider-Man, Chris Hemsworth's new take on Thor, Zoe Saldana as Gamora and of course, again, Josh Brolin as Thanos are the noteworthy standouts. Every character has its defined actor, the chemistry flows like a fine wine as the acting gives life to IW's superb story. The last decade of Marvel movies has brought incalculable joy to millions of fans across the globe. It's given us characters to relate to, to root for and to cherish. It's perfected "the Marvel formula", a recipe that no other studio has yet to replicate, pumping out one gold star after the next, building a connected film franchise like none other. And now, it's given us Infinity War, the epic crowning achievement of the Marvel Cinematic Universe.  10/10

With so many characters, the Russo brothers made an intelligent choice to center the emotional core of the film within a new character and the only one large enough within the narrative space to justify it: the antagonist. Outside of him, the movie's essentially the biggest episode of a serial ever. It does that quite well, but it ends up squeezing out Thanos a bit. He's good and enough to anchor a movie around, but everything else around him is pure spectacle and little else. I say little else because all of our heroes get their moments. Thor talking about everything he's lost. Vision and Scarlet Witch's little romance taking shape. Peter Quill's grief at the loss of a loved one. It's all there, but it almost all depends on things outside this movie to work. Not that anyone would ever come into this movie without having at least some knowledge of the myriad of franchises that precedes it, but I think it deadens the impact of the moments since the emotional workload isn't held within this movie itself. This isn't like the final moments of a three-part movie like The Lord of the Rings, this is the culmination of more than twenty films, each with their own adventures and main characters, that end up tying together here. So what you do have is a well-produced series of epic fights and events in the vein of a man on a mission type story, peppered with small character moments, revolving around the character of Thanos. Thanos is the biggest threat the Avengers have faced (other than Dormmamu who was going to wipe out the entire universe in Doctor Strange, I guess), and he's one of the better antagonists. I don't think he's miles better than Hela, Loki, or Vulture, but he's definitely in that league. He's a titan driven by an ideal, and he's pure psychopath. Some people put forward the idea that Thanos could use the power of the Infinity Stones to double the universe's resources, but that misses the point of the character. He's a Malthusian through and through. He sees intelligent life as a cancer, infecting the universe, and that's what must be wiped out. He's so psychotic that to even dream of reasoning with him is asinine. He's committed, and he demonstrate that commitment to his vision by sacrificing his beloved adopted daughter to gain one of the stones (the Soul Stone). Meanwhile, our heroes take on several different related goals. There's the attempt to remove and destroy the Mind Stone from Vision's forehead. There's Thor trying to replace Mjolnir. There's Iron Man leading Dr. Strange and Spider-Man (joined by most of the Guardians of the Galaxy) to fight Thanos before he gains full strength on the titan's destroyed home planet. The story is structured around these different tasks, each told with the Marvel brand of quippy humor, seasoned with just enough emotion borrowed from the franchise's history, and built to all crescendo at the same time. That crescendo, which really takes up the last hour or so of the film, is something to admire. There are so many pieces moving and so many parts flying in so many different locations that the fact that it's easy to understand who is involved in what and why on a consistent basis is kind of remarkable. The Russo Brothers have evolved a lot in terms of action cinematography since The Winter Soldier. They still have a preference for shallow depth of field, handheld camera, and close up photography, but they edit it a bit less frantically and pull back more than enough to firmly establish geography. One thing they haven't really grown on, though, is visuals in general. It's an interesting contrast to watch so many of these movies in a row. Just a few movies back was Guardians of the Galaxy: Vol. 2. In it, everything with brightly colored with array of beautiful things. When Thor shows up in the Guardian's ship, the same location that was so easily bathed in color in the previous movie has been dialed back to almost complete darkness. The movie as a whole isn't dark (the fight in Wakanda is very brightly lit), but it's fascinating to see some of the same locations and costumes that had been so colorful drained of it all in this. I think it's an incorrect visual choice for the franchise, especially as it embraces its cosmic side. It needs to be crazier visually instead of dark and "grounded". Still, I find Thanos a good villain, the ride overall fun and engaging, and just wish that it didn't rely so much on the previous movies and looked brighter and more colorful. For a movie that I could not see as being anything other than an expensive mess, that's quite an accomplishment.

It is finally here.. the culmination of 10 years of multiple MCU story lines spanning 18 movies and ship-load of superheroes and their support cast which we have grown to love. Thanks to the well orchestrated marketing campaign as well as the gradual buildup over the years through all the story arcs converging to this climactic showdown, the tsunami of expectations for Infinity War had hit a crescendo before the release. Credit to the director duo of Russo brothers who have managed to deliver despite such stupendous expectations and hype. The movie is chock-a-block with our favourite superheroes and towering above all of them, is their nemesis - the mad titan Thanos who spells death, doom and destruction from the word go, as he sets out on a quest to capture all six infinity stones which would make him the most powerful entity of the universe. While the narrative is indeed weighed down by the sheer mass of the material on hand and the multiple characters vying for screen-time, the directors have managed to provide space for almost all of them to come into their own. Given the scale of the challenge at hand, the sinister designs of Thanos and his team and his superlative power which continues to multiply as the movie progresses, there is a palpable dark tinge that permeates the movie. Despite being shrouded under the dark cloud of impending doom an gloom, the narrative is frequently funny with clever cracking quips coming from the clash of several superhero sized egos as well as genuinely tongue-in-cheek conversations as all these characters get to know each other. The action is often frenetic and the set pieces are brilliantly mounted on a dazzling scale with scope for almost every character to shine in brief bursts. In a movie of this scale, with more superhero per minute than any other venture, Josh Brolin is impressively menacing as the invincible, Thanos who seeks to bring balance to the universe even if it involves wiping half of all lives, including many of our favourite superheroes, at the snap of his fingers. While some of the outcomes are on expected lines as indicated in the many trailers and teasers, the Russo brothers have packed quite a few nasty surprises that could leave the audience gawking, especially - an epic cliffhanger ending. As the dust settles after a feverish run-time of almost 160 minutes and an audacious climax (yup every minute counts.. including the end credit scene), the audience are left at a perilous precipice that is shocking and desperately seeking answers to multiple questions from the sequel that is slated to hit the screens next year. Till then... we are left to MARVEL ... What could be lying beyond this insidious infinity ?

Starring: Robert Downey Jr (Iron Man), Chris Evans (Steve Rogers), Chris Hemsworth (Thor), Mark Ruffalo (Hulk), Scarlett Johansson (Natasha Romanoff), Don Cheedle (Warachine), Benedict Cumberbatch (Dr. Strange), Tom Holland (Spider-Man), Chadwick Boseman (Black Panther), Zoe Saldana (Gamora), Karen Gillon (Nebula), Tom Hiddleston (Loki), Paul Bettany (Vision), Elizabeth Olsen (Wanda Maximoff), Anthony Mackie (Sam Wilson), Sebastian Stan (Winter Soldier), Danai Gurira (Okoye), Pom Klementieff (Mantis), Dave Bautista (Drax), Vin Diesel (Groot), Bradley Cooper (Rocket), Chris Pratt (Star Lord), Josh Brolin (Thanos)
Plot: Earth and the whole universe is threatened by Thanos, who believes that the world is better with half of the people in the universe killed, and the Avengers are the only ones who can stop him...but will they be enough? Review: This movie is the darkest entry in the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU), and the most epic in terms of scope and the threat that harms the world. This movie is not only a great movie, but a monumnental achievement and testament to Marvel's ability to realize its incredible vision. After 10 years and 19 movies Marvel has clearly shown that they know how to bring in hardcore and casual fans to the movies to see heroes dressed up in tights and saving the world. If you have been following this series and have watched most to all of the previous 18 MCU, this is a very satisfying payoff movie as it follows most of the heroes in the MCU. The Russos really outdid themselves, and through incredible editing and story telling they managed to tell a cohesive story that juggled numerous characters. Though there were so many characters in this movie, the movie gave most of the characters great moments. The standouts were probably Zoe Saldana as Gamora, and Josh Brolin as Thanos. You believed their relationship as daughter and father respectively and you felt the emotional consequences of their relationship and what that relationship entailed. This was also Thanos' movie. He is without a doubt, my favorite villain in the MCU now and he is up there with Jordan's Killmonger, Hiddleston's Loki, and Keaton's Vulture. Brolin exudes such confidence, ferocity, and charisma in his performance that he sells the fact that he really believes what he is doing is right no matter how evil he seemed. I actually found myself agreeing with some of Thanos' reasonings at some points of the movie. This was an unconventional narrative driven movie. It truly stands as a monument to Marvel's ability to deliver a different and unconventional comic book movie experience, and many studios will come to look at this as a paragon of how to do a payoff movie in a series. Many may even compare this to "Lord of the Rings: Two Towers" (2002), or "Star Wars: Empire Strikes Back" (1980) in its structure, but I believe this movie even stands apart from those movies. The only drawbacks that I saw was the fact that if this was your first MCU movie you will have no idea who the characters were and will be lost when watching this movie. Also, because there are so many characters in the movie some major characters don't get a chance to show up and get more moments, but I expected this going in. Truly, not only a great comic book movie, but an incredible movie watching experience.

Ready? Here we go: 1. I love Avengers 1 & 2 and I was saddened a bit that Joss Whedon wasn't coming back as director for the 3rd installment. But after seeing Winter Soldier and Civil War, the Russo Brothers were the best men for the job and sure enough they didn't disappoint. 2. The most impressive thing about the movie is how it was able to fit more than 20 major characters in, each getting the appropriate screen time (Black Panther gets just enough considering we just saw him a couple of months ago), nothing feels rushed and/or badly edited (Justice League, Suicide Squad, anyone?) 3. While it is a Russo Brothers movie, we still get the Taiki Waititi Thor, the James Gunn Guardians of the Galaxy and all the others seamlessly interwoven that's why the running time of 149 minutes of excitement, joy and sadness just quickly went by. 4. I have to agree with the critics that while the story isn't it's main strength, in my opinion the movie still works because A) it was setup nicely by the previous MCU installments and B) each and every character was perfectly cast. From Tom Holland's Peter Parker (sorry Tobey Maguire) all the way to Josh Brolin's Thanos, no one seems out of place or trying hard to fit in. 5. Speaking of Thanos, he was so well-written and played that he almost got my buy-in on his desire to eradicate half of life in the universe in order to restore balance and allow the planet to heal and recuperate. I remember when news broke out about the first Avenger movie, I counted the days until I saw it in the cinema. Now, it's just 367 days left until Avengers 4 is released. I was thinking after this story arc, can they still top themselves? What else can they do that we haven't seen already? While there are other story lines that are worth telling, will they be able to recast the actors just as well? All things considered these are all good problems to have, they are still problems just the same. But with 19 movies already out and plenty more in the pipeline, I think the MCU has sorted all of this out and all we have to do is pony up the money.

Unless you've been living under a rock for the past decade or so you might have heard of a little production company by the name of Marvel Studios. Creating motion picture adaptations of Marvel Comics properties, they've had a surprisingly consistent track record for delivering satisfying big budget superhero entertainment. The fact that they also managed to tie everything together into a cohesive shared universe is something that frankly hadn't been seen to that extent in movies before. All of the care that went into these productions culminated in 2018's "Avengers: Infinity War" and its direct sequel, 2019's "Avengers: Endgame". Together they proved to be a fitting capper to Marvel's journey that began with "Iron Man" in 2008. First of all, it's important to recognize that this movie is part one of a two part story. I didn't realize this when I originally watched the movie, so I was somewhat disappointed that the story wasn't brought to a resolution. Later on, when rewatching the movie ahead of the concluding chapter, I got a better appreciation of what the movie was meant to be. As had been hinted at for years, "Infinity War" finally marked the entrance of Thanos into the Marvel universe as a major villain. He seeks to acquire the six Infinity Stones, which will make him powerful enough to restore balance to the universe... by laying half of it to waste. Naturally, our heroes the Avengers aren't about to just let that happen. However, Thanos's power increases with the acquisition of each new stone, so stopping him becomes a race against time. For a movie that's the culmination of 19 previous films, a memorable villain was a must. Luckily, Josh Brolin's portrayal of Thanos is one of the most memorable in the Marvel canon. No doubt much of the credit goes to the original creator of the character (Jim Starlin) but the fact is that Thanos gives the impression that he's someone who could give the Avengers a run for their money. In fact, he's such a formidable foe that the threat of defeat is more palpable than in any previous Marvel movie. That his motivations are also interesting from a philosophical point of view is another point in the movie's favour. Having a compelling villain is of course a crucial element in any superhero movie but in this case the sheer scale of the undertaking is impressive in and of itself. Featuring a star-studded cast of Marvel veterans in the various heroic roles, it's amazing that the producers managed to keep the shared universe alive this long just to be able to put this movie together in the first place. That they managed to keep the movie from collapsing under the weight of its stars is another testament to their commitment to quality. Despite a fairly hefty two and a half hour runtime, the movie is nicely paced and gives a reasonable amount of screentime to all involved. My only real complaint is that the final act's impact is somewhat muted by the utter improbability that certain characters will be gone for good since they already had sequels in the pipeline. Surely they could have stuck to characters whose fate was less certain? "Infinity War" may not be the type of movie I'd watch for awards-worthy work on either side of the camera but as a feat of production I think that it and its (superior) sequel are nearly unparalleled. It makes me wonder if "Endgame" might be shown some love at the next Oscars ceremony. I mean, "Black Panther" was nominated for Best PIcture and that was arguably more about cultural impact than the actual merits of the production (though I wouldn't have argued if Michael B. Jordan was nominated). In any case, Marvel fans don't need any convincing to watch this movie. For others, this probably isn't the best starting point.

I'm not a big comic book fan, or movies made from them, or blockbuster movies in general, but I really enjoyed this. Yes, as others have said, it is too long -- I think they could have taken time from each of the battle scenes which would have cut the overall running time nicely without losing anything really important. Yeah, the CGI stuff is fun, but after a while, I get bored with it all. I watched this via Nexflix, so I ended up watching it in two parts which helped to keep it fresher for me. Previously I had watched both Guardians of the Galaxy and Thor, both of which I really liked. Another reviewer mentioned that the naysayers needed to have watched the earlier individual superhero movies as their story lines were meant to meet here. That does make sense to me. Although, if you were to watch this cold turkey with a relatively open mind, then you should be able to pretty much suss out what is happening without all of the other back grounding. Which I guess quite a number of reviewers here weren't interested in doing. Their loss. This movie was really funny! The dialogue with the self-effacing humour and the inside jokes was so nicely done. This was what I also liked about Guardians and Thor. I almost didn't watch those movies because I thought they were going to be just all action (which as already mentioned, bores me pretty quickly), but I was pleasantly surprised. I'm now actually more interested in seeing the other individual hero movies (Iron Man, Hulk, etc), if they're going to have this kind of banter and lightness in them. I'm always more interested in the human/android/etc interactions than the never ending battle stuff. I loved Thor always calling Rocket a bunny! In fact this makes me think that what was put down as a "character error" here about him always pronouncing the destination as "Nivadellir" instead of "Nidavellir" actually wasn't an error at all. As he tells Rocket, he's been a God for over two thousand years... he doesn't really give a crap if he's pronouncing something incorrectly, or calling Rocket a bunny instead of a fox. And well, unless you're Captain Kirk, the average person (or character in a movie) just isnt going to question a God. Hahaha. I also enjoyed that the writing of the main characters and the actors playing them actually had some complexity and depth (once again, keeping my attention from wandering, lol). Thanos in particular was so well done. Like really well done (kudos to the writers and Josh Brolin). It is rare that the villain is done this way. But a villain that makes sense and that you can agree with on some levels is far scarier than a cardboard box stereotype. It's the people who you can relate to, or even like, that can hurt you the most. The Thanos character brought up some important issues. Not everyone and everything can live. It is heartbreaking. It is terrible, but it's true. There just isn't the room and resources on this Earth in particular to keep up with the never ending onslaught of human carelessness. But who are we going to trust to make those awful decisions? Who would have the psychological strength to make them, and be partisan about it? As Thanos said, the choices are made irrespective of gender, race or wealth. It was not done without personal loss and pain. I loved at the ending when he's sitting up high, looking out, and feeling such loneliness. I also love that Thanos's endgame created a quandary for me, a viewer, cos I'm not quite sure who's side I'm now. Is Thanos really a villain, or are the super heroes (and the rest of us) not looking at the whole picture? The ending was quite interesting. It wasn't all happy, happy. There were terrible losses, which were hard to watch. Although, it does make me think that as the other superhero movies were a portal into this movie, then this movie will also a portal into the next sequel where these losses will be righted. I hope so anyway. P.S. The battle in Wakanda reminded me of a crazy teched out version of the big battle in The Return of the King.

Now that Avengers: Endgame has been released, it seems high time to re-evaluate its predecessor, Infinity War. Endgame was certainly able to do more with setup than simply resolving it, in fact introducing new arcs and conflicts to keep the movie interesting in its own right. Regardless, Infinity War deserves much praise for being able to set up the dramatic scenario of Endgame, while being entertaining on its own.
Infinity War centers around anti-hero Thanos (Josh Brolin) on his quest to collect all six Infinity Stones, in order to wipe out half of all living beings. His reasoning? "This universe's resources are finite. If left unchecked, life will cease to exist."
The film's opening scenes depict Loki failing to trick Thanos in an attempt to save his brother, Thor, and protect the Tesseract, which holds the Space Stone. Despite a surprise attack from Hulk, which seems to turn the tides, Thanos eventually overpowers him and acquires his second Infinity Stone. In this very first sequence, Infinity War introduces its key theme of inevitability. Time and again, the Avengers appear to gain the advantage, only for Thanos to beat them back and continue his destructive plot.
In one of the film's most iconic scenes, Doctor Strange (Benedict Cumberbatch) uses the Time Stone to look into "14,000,605" possible futures. When Tony Stark asks, "In how many do we win?" he pauses, then replies "One." With the extra context of Endgame, we know that this singular future is the one in which Thanos "wins," and then the Avengers triumph in Endgame (more on that later). At the time of first viewing, however, Doctor Strange's lines imply, (in one of the most intensely mocked moments of Infinity War) when Strange simply gives the Time Stone to Thanos, that the universe has already lost. This perfectly sets up Endgame, where the Avengers crawl back from a world which has already lost.
But! in Endgame, the ultimate theme of inevitability is turned on its head, and the viewer realizes that Doctor Strange's odd decisions were actually necessary to defeat Thanos. Rewatching Infinity War now not only dramatically recontextualizes the "14,000,605" scene in a sad new way, but also totally rewrites Strange's apparent 'turn to the dark side' as a clever ploy, establishing that, with Strange's help, the salvation of the universe in Endgame is what was truly inevitable.
This fantastic scriptwriting, by the Russo brothers, is what truly brings these two films into masterpieces. Needless to say, the graphical effects are also likely the best and most believable ever seen, from miniscule dust particles adding immersion to perfectly rendered faces, like Hulk and Thanos. Aside from that, the most common complaints about both films are from poor character development. The role of Drax (Dave Bautista) was mostly unfunny crude comments in Infinity War, and he (thankfully) isn't present much in Endgame. Even more egregious is the role of Captain Marvel (Brie Larson), who is not at all present in Infinity War, and barely contributes in Endgame despite being portrayed as incredibly powerful. Granted, Infinity War and Endgame were filmed before Captain Marvel (Brie Larson's introduction). Thus, the character was not yet established and didn't even have an actor in time for Infinity War. Still, this obscenely powerful character being absent from Infinity War, when she is needed most, is not at all excused by "there are a lot of other planets in the universe" (her brief explanation from Endgame).
In any case, it seems apparent that Anthony and Joe Russo are much less interested in individual characters than their fellow Marvel Cinematic Universe directors like James Gunn. It's clear that Avengers: Infinity War and Endgame prioritized their overall directions more. The way these two films take totally contrasting stances with the common theme of inevitability gives each film a unique flavor. Where Infinity War felt like a spiraling fall into calamity, Endgame feels like a desperate crawl towards salvation, eventually leaving a single, inevitable outcome of victory. Ultimately, Endgame seems to outshine its predecessor, but largely because of its impressive setup thanks to Infinity War. Like the first and last acts of the same story, the first builds tension and ends in climax, and the latter manages to bring the climax to a close, rewriting the tragedy of the first, with some major lasting sacrifice still in effect. Truly, there is no better outcome to get us excited for Spiderman: Far From Home!

Avengers Infinity War is a 140-minute tornado that comes in and goes out punching with the intent to kill. It requires several viewings just to comprehend all the material this film contains. Its strengths are in its ludicrously intense levels of action and mayhem, as well as a great performance from Josh Brolin, who finally brings to life the most well-developed MCU villain to date. Weaknesses? Some pretty hard-to-ignore plot holes and an ending that fails to evoke the emotion in the way it so enthusiastically tries to. Final Remarks? Avengers: Infinity War is for anyone looking for an explosive, edge-of-your-seat adventure, but those seeking a richer and deeper emotional resonance will gravitate towards Endgame.

I have not seen all 21 films in the story arc that serves as the background for this penultimate episode in the MCU series that will soon culminate in "Avengers: Endgame". Seeing those films could only help, but it is not necessary. A general knowledge of the Marvel characters is probably enough to enjoy this wonderful spectacle. A complex villain named Thanos is determined to collect all six of the infinity stones, which would give him nearly infinite power. An extraordinarily large cast of Marvel superheroes combines forces to stop him. CGI is used in abundance to create a non-stop display of environments and conflicts. Like other Marvel films, the production relies on three major cornerstones to create an enjoyable experience: 1. Comedy is used to offset the heavy emotional elements of the film. Sometimes this is achieved by juxtaposing grandiose speech with commonplace speech, often employing pop culture references. 2. Suspension of disbelief is required in large doses to allow the writers to manipulate the epic elements of the story for conflict and dramatic effect. 3. Larger-than-life environments are used for their wow factor. "Infinity War" has these three elements in spades. The plot requires our heroes to overcome nearly impossible odds, say 1 in 14,000,605. Disparate factions of the Marvel superheroes collection are introduced to each other in an all out battle. The film ends with the ultimate cliffhanger, especially considering that Marvel promises a grand conclusion that will reset Marvel's future forever.

There is no film, or series that is comparable to the Avengers entire series and Infinity War completely blew Age of Ultron away. I think the directors, and writers for this movie deserve a ton of credit for how they wove all the MCU movies to this point together without skipping a beat. What they did was so complex, yet it came out very easy to follow as I watched the movie. One mistake anywhere throughout the film easily could have blown everything, but I thought it was flawless. The last 2 Transformers movies are a good example of a high budget movie where a couple mistakes early on just take all the credibility out of the viewing experience and then the viewer can't help but roll their eyes throughout. I double down: Infinity Wars maintained credibility throughout and there were absolutely no character hiccups. I'd like to point out that in the most star studded cast ever Josh Brolin stood out and completely stole the show, in his portrayal of Thanos. They did a really cool job with the CGI to sort of make Thanos resemble Brolin and also follow his movement. I assume they would have had Brolin in some sort of a suit so they could easily mimic his movements for the character, but his voice acting was on another level. The way he inflected the tone just sent chills down my spine, and sent the message across to me of exactly what Thanos is all about. Like you can tell from the tone in his voice that he's been wiping out planets and civilizations for so long that he feels no remorse, and he's actually doing a good deed to the Universe every time. The scariest part of Thanos is that he truly believes he's the good-guy even though we've all established that he is the most evil dude in the Universe. I couldn't have imagined anyone else coming anywhere near how well Josh Brolin portrayed this megalomaniac! They did such a great job of casting every character I think. So far there is only 2 actors that I didn't like cast for the role they're in: 1. I don't like the way Danai Gurira plays Okoye who is T'Challa's right hand lady in Wakanda. She just always seems like she's trying too hard to be tough. The other person I don't like the casting of and has me sort of dreading End Game is Brie Larson who plays Captain Marvel who is supposed to save everyone in the next movie as we got the little Egg in the final scene after the credits of Infinity War. Other than that the cast is great. The balance of all this different colourful personalities of super-hero's seems to be spot on here. I highly recommend watching this 10/10 high-octane, super-smash, block-buster hit!!

It's all been building to this. Every movie, every new hero, every cosmic artifact and alien civilization. It's all been leading to the big showdown. And it is magnificent. The battles, the team-ups, the twists and turns, every moment of it is spectacular. This is what we've been waiting for. Infinity War wastes no time getting started. Beginning right where Ragnarok ended, it hits the ground running and never stops. The fights and the deaths start in the first scene, and momentum builds and builds from there as Thanos's plans are set into motion and the heroes rally to stop them. From New York to Wakanda to the edges of the universe the action is almost nonstop, pausing just long enough to let us catch our breath. The numerous brawls and battles are fast paced, beautifully staged and photographed, and varied enough to never get tiresome. Black Panther's climactic battle in Wakanda was awesome. Infinity War's is at least ten times better. This is also a movie brimming with character. And characters. Virtually every hero and anti-hero Marvel has introduced up to this point. No time is spent on introductions because know them already. If you don't then you have some serious catching up to do before you watch this. Chris Pratt is still as shameless, vain, and hilarious as ever as Star Lord. Tom Holland is still spouting movie references and trying to impress everyone as Spider-Man. And teen Groot is your average moody teenager, only with superpowers and a three-word vocabulary. And with all of them thrown together there are some awesome team ups. Iron Man and Doctor Strange. Spider-Man and Star Lord. Thor and Rocket Racoon! Even with so many characters in play every one of them gets their chance to shine, both in battle and with the lines they deliver. The chemistry between them all is remarkable considering that many of them have never appeared on screen together before. Of course great heroes need great villains to fight, and Infinity War delivers. Though most viewers have never heard of them, Corvus Glaive, Proxima Midnight, Black Dwarf and especially the Ebony Maw make an immediate impression with their sense of menace and deadly skills. But nothing compares to Thanos himself. He's not just Marvel's most dangerous villain, he's their best. He is incredibly powerful, undeniably brilliant, and absolutely mad. Not raving lunatic or spontaneously violent mad. His madness is cold, calculating, and filled with certainty that every ounce of death and suffering he inflicts serves a higher purpose. With his power and single-minded determination, he is an absolute force of nature and watching him in battle in simply incredible. For those who worried that Marvel was getting too goofy, fear not. The tone here is as far as you can get from Ragnarok and still be in the Marvel universe.
The humor is still here, and it still works. There are lines that will have you laughing out loud. And thank goodness, because otherwise all the death and destruction would get DC level brooding. Infinity War is a movie that knows the value of a little comic relief, but it really knows how to be serious- even somber- when it needs to be. It can be a real emotional roller coaster, so buckle up and don't get too attached to anyone. Now I'll admit that the story is mainly there to string together the big superhero fights. That said it's pretty good, with multiple converging plot threads and a fair number of twists and turns, some of which are downright jaw dropping. Peter Dinklage's mystery appearance is better than anything we could have hoped for, but there are much more shocking reveals as characters and plot threads that were seemingly forgotten years ago reemerge. And the ending... well not everyone will be pleased, but it took guts, and it's one hell of a cliffhanger. Part two may only be a year off, but the wait is going to feel infinite.

To be honest, I've been watching these Avengers movies since I was 8 years old. It was actually the first PG-13 movie my parents let me see, afters piles of weeks of heavy convincing. With him almost a year ago, I saw Avengers: Infinity war. I was blown away by this movie, from the incredible acting by a star studded cast, to the plot twist at the end that will leave any person in the theater speechless. When the lights turned back on, everyone around me was either crying or their jaws were laying on the floor from being so shocked by the ending. From the astonishing editing, to the great camera work, this movie swept me off my feet.
I usually admit whether I'm biased towards a certain something or in this case a certain franchise, but there is no need to admit being biased in this case, this was hands down of the greatest movies i've ever seen.
The plot of this movie is that Thanos( the most powerful Titan in the universe), is trying to get rid of half of Earth's population. The only way he can accomplish this is by retrieving all 6 infinity stones (these 6 stones are the only reason the universe is a thing, at least in this made up world). Thanos believes that our world's population is becoming too large, and killing off half our population will solve so many problems. After bombarding asgard( basically like heaven in this world) and killing almost all their people, Thanos retrieves the second out of six infinity stones. This is when he orders his army( the black order) to go to earth and retrieve 2 more stones, while he goes out into the depths of the galaxy and gets the two someone only of his power and stature could get. Meanwhile on earth, the almighty universe protectors, The Avengers, are going through a rough patch. They recently broke up( or as the hulk says, Like a band, broke up?"). They got into a huge argument about if they wanted the Avengers to be government run or if they wanted to continue running themselves. Playboy Billionaire tony stark(or iron man) is basically retired, but is then forced to come out of retirement due to being contacted by Hugo Strange(Dr. Strange) an is told that by both him and Bruce banner(Hulk) that Thanos is coming and won't stop until he gets all six infinity stones and ends half of the living population on earth as a whole. After fighting off the Black Order from earth, Stark and 16 year old Peter Parker(Spider Man) follow a spaceship up into space to take back a kidnapped Dr. Strange and the almighty time stone he carries and protects with his life. After saving strange and killing the wizard from the Order( Ebony Maw), they crash land on Thanos's homeland, Titan. They then develop a plan to lure Thanos in and kill him. Meanwhile back on earth, the hero's from the other parts of the world keep trying to fight off the Black Order, but the Order fights back and the battle for the infinity stones commences. Who wins? You'll have to watch to find out!
The acting in this movie blew me away. The star studded cast (Robert Downey Jr, Chris Evans, Scarlett Johansson, Josh Brolin, Chris Hemsworth, Chris Pratt, Benedict Cumberbatch, etc.) made the movie the blockbuster breaking film it was. I could really feel the sadness of when Tony Stark(Robert Downey Jr.) had to leave his wife from earth to go and try to save the world, instead of staying behind and starting a family like he promised in the very beginning of the movie( and i'm sure before then as well).They always say great actors make movies what they are. I have to say without this all star lineup of a cast, this movie wouldn't of been close to being as good as it is. Also, I believe less people would have paid to see this movie if the movie had actors (and actresses) of a lesser caliber.
I have to admit, i'm surprised this movie didn't take 10 years to make. I say that because I was shocked about how realistic the aliens and the other made up characters looked in this movie. I have to tip my hat to the film editors, their job was outstanding and i'm surprised they didn't recently win an oscar for best film editing at the Oscars. The perfect example is the final fight scene on Titan with some of the Avengers vs Thanos. All that camera work goes unnoticed(you'll have to see it to know what i'm talking about). The camera work in this movie was also great. In the intense action scenes, both behind the camera or behind the computer, this was one of the main reasons that i'm praising this movie.
If I had to compare this movie to another movie like this( not counting the other like 30 Avenger movies made), I would compare it to it's crosstown rival, Justice League. I compare Infinity war to this movie because of the similar plots and the similar use of superpowers in both stories. I also compare it to The Dark Knight Rises, because it also relates to the topic of being a superhero and protecting what you believe in. That is what I saw almost automatically when I saw this movie, and that is why I wanted to compare these movies together.
After this movie, I think totally differently about movies as a whole. This movie change my way of thinking due to the fact that the ending was so shocking. ALso, in this movie, the directors and writers make you believe one thing will happen, that this movie will end like every other superhero movie ever made. But then suddenly, it totally switches, and the plot that you have been led to believe doesn't happen. Trust me, by the time the credits are rolling and the lights come back on, your eyes will be wide, and you will be shocked. This movie was spectacular in every way possible, and I can't wait for part two!

Thanos, after seeing him in previous easter eggs, I worried he was going to be a classic villain with no humanity. But he's not. In Infinity War, Thanos is a human. He has his background, he has his value. The fact that he only kills to bring balance to the Universe after his world was destroyed indicates that he has human feelings and he wants to solve the unsolvable problem.
